choices.text: For smoothening of edges in amputation surgery
To remove fibrous tissue from non-union site

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is used for:(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Used as a bone nibbler

 

BONE NIBBLER

 

  • Bone Nibbler/Bone Rongeurs are like pliers with a heavy, pointed jaw.
  • With their heavy construction, bone nibblers are used for gnawing holes in bones during Orthopedic surgery.
  • The scoop-shaped tip of the rongeur is used for gouging the bone.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. For cutting ribs in thoracic surgery. Rib Shears are surgical instruments used in cardiothoracic surgeries to cut bones, especially ribs. They absorb the shock of the cut and provide an atraumatic experience. 

 

 

Option B. For smoothening of edges in amputation surgery. Putti Bone Rasp is used for orthopedic surgeries that require mild reshaping and handling of bones. It is a double-ended instrument used for debriding and smoothing the bone edges after the amputation surgery.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

The image shown in the question is of a bone nibbler which is used to gnaw holes in the bones during the surgery.

questions.text: A patient complains that he often gets troubled at night during sleep by tingling and numbness that involves his lateral three digits. He further explains that symptoms are relieved as he lays his arms hanging from the bed. Correct regarding the condition is: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CTS: Durkan test

 

CARPAL TUNNEL SYNDROME

 

  • It is the entrapment of median nerve at the wrist beneath the flexor retinaculum
  • Clinical features:
    • 8 times more common in females
    • Usual age group is 50 years
    • Burning pain, paresthesia, tingling and numbness in median nerve distribution



       
    • Pain increased by activities, more troublesome at night; relieved by handing the arm over the side of bed or by shaking the arm
    • Clumsiness and weakness in tasks requiring fine manipulation
       
  • Special tests:
    • Sensory symptoms can be reproduced by percussion over the median nerve – Tinel’s sign
    • Sensory symptoms can also be reproduced by holding the wrist in full flexion for a minute – Phalen’s test/Reverse Phalen’s test

 

 

1. Phalen’s test; 2. Reverse Phalen’s test

 

  • The most specific test for carpal tunnel syndrome is Durkans test – Direct compression over the median nerve – best clinical test – done by holding wrist in slight flexion and directly compressing the nerve by applying pressure to proximal wrist crease for 30 seconds – development of pain, paresthesia or numbness indicates a positive test.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CTS: Froment sign. Froment’s sign is seen in cases of ulnar nerve palsy where the adductor pollicis is paralysed. The patient is made to hold a book between the thumb and the palm. In case of ulnar nerve palsy, the patient will hold the book using the flexor pollicis longus muscle, which will produce flexion at the IP joint.

 

 

This sign is specific of ulnar nerve palsy and will be negative in carpal tunnel syndrome.

 

Option C. Guyon canal syndrome: Froment sign. Guyon Canal syndrome, also known as Ulnar Tunnel Syndrome/ulnar tunnel syndrome/handlebar palsy, is a relatively rare peripheral ulnar neuropathy. It is defined as a compression of the distal ulnar nerve at the level of the wrist as it enters the hand through a space called ulnar tunnel or Guyon canal. The clinical presentation can be purely sensory, purely motor or both depending on the location of the nerve compression. Froment’s sign will be positive in this case.

 

Option D. Guyon canal syndrome: Durkan test. Durkan test is the most specific and sensitive for carpal tunnel syndrome only.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given clinical symptoms of the patient suggest presence of carpal tunnel syndrome. The most specific test to check median nerve compression in the carpal tunnel is the Durkan’s Test.

questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4

 

Option D)

 

SURGICAL INSTRUMENTS

 

 

Educational objective:

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis based on this X-ray?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Patella fracture

 

  • The given image shows a comminuted patellar fracture with the fracture lines visible and moderate joint effusion.

 

 

PATELLA FRACTURE

 

  • Patellar fractures are usually caused by direct trauma, such as a fall from standing height onto the flexed knee or a dashboard impact from a motor vehicle collision.
  • These fractures can also be caused by rapid contracture of the quadriceps with a flexed knee that can lead to loss of the extensor mechanism.
  • Patella fractures account for 1% of all skeletal injuries and 6-9% are open fractures.
  • Male to female ratio is 2:1 and most fractures occur in 20-50 year olds.
  • On inspection, a palpable patellar defect, significant hemarthrosis, and lacerations, abrasions in setting of open fractures are found.
  • The patient has an inability to perform straight leg raise.
  • The extensor mechanism and retinaculum are disrupted.
  • Lateral view radiograph is the best view for transverse fractures. It is obtained in 30⁰ knee flexion.

 

Lateral view showing effusion in the knee

 

  • Axial view is the best view for vertical fractures.

 

 

  • An important differential diagnosis of patellar fracture is bipartite patella which can be mistaken as patella fracture. It shows smooth and regular borders on the radiograph; can be bilateral in 50% cases, and is characteristically seen in superolateral position.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tibial Condyle fracture: Tibial Plateau fractures are periarticular injuries of the proximal tibia frequently associated with soft tissue injury. Incidence is 1-2% of all fractures. It can be caused in males in age group of 40s due to high energy trauma, and in females of age group of 70s due to low energy falls. Incidence of lateral plateau fracture is 70-80% (due to valgus load), bicondylar is 10-30% (due to axial load), and of medial plateau is 10-20% (due to varus load). In a high energy trauma, there is fracture-dislocation of the medial plateau with soft tissue injuries (meniscus and ACL tear, common peroneal nerve injury). Low energy traumas cause lateral plateau fractures. AP, lateral and oblique radiograph views are helpful; oblique view helps in determining amount of depression. AP view shows depressed articular surface and abnormal joint alignment. Lateral view shows posteromedial fracture lines and abnormal tibial slope.

 


AP and Lateral view showing tibial condyle/plateau fracture

 

Option B. Rheumatoid arthritis: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory autoimmune disease of unknown etiology that affects approximately 1% of the world population, with approximately 50% of adults being unable to work within 10 years of disease onset. The disease involves synovial joints and leads to progressive joint destruction. The knee joint is commonly involved in RA. Severe destruction of the articular cartilage and menisci is a characteristic feature of RA. Bone marrow edema and bone erosion can both also be found, but are less characteristic.

 

 

Option D. Hemarthrosis of Knee Joint: Hemarthrosis is bleeding into a joint cavity. It is best diagnosed with arthrocentesis and synovial fluid analysis. Traumatic injury is the most common cause of hemarthrosis. Non-traumatic hemarthrosis can be caused by bleeding disorders that are either hereditary or acquired. Hereditary bleeding disorders include hemophilia and inherited coagulation factor deficiency disorders. Examples of acquired bleeding disorders include advanced liver or renal disease, vitamin K deficiency, disseminated intravascular coagulation, or anticoagulation medication use. Post-operative recurrent hemarthrosis is frequently associated with total knee arthroplasty. The preferred initial imaging modality is plain film radiology of the involved joint and surrounding bones. If a fracture is not seen but strongly suspected, further evaluation with a CT scan is warranted. MRI may be able to diagnose ligamentous or other soft tissue injuries as the cause of hemarthrosis. Ultrasound (US) can help identify and characterize intra-articular fluid collections. The synovial fluid from a hemarthrosis may appear red, pink, or brown depending on the cause of bleeding. Aspiration of the joint and subsequent analysis can differentiate simple effusion, hemarthrosis, lipohemarthrosis, and septic arthritis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows the comminuted fracture of the patella.

questions.text: A child was brought to the emergency department with multiple injuries, which included a femur fracture as well. He developed confusion, dyspnea, and a rash over his body. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fat embolism

 

  • Fat embolism although should be diagnosed with trauma to long bone, usually Femur and clinical presentation of pulmonary involvement, CNS depression and skin involvement (Petechiae).

  • The diagnosis is considered usually after 48 hours. 

 

Fracture Femur with Breathlessness after 48 hours think of it!

 

  • Fat embolism refers to the presence of fat globules in vital organs and peripheral circulation after fracture of a long bone or other major trauma. 

  • Fat embolism is more commonly seen in patients with multiple fractures and in fractures involving lower limbs especially femur.

  • Clinical Presentation:

    • Early warning signs are a slight rise in temperature and pulse rate (tachycardia).

    • The classical triad of fat embolism syndrome is:

      1. Respiratory symptoms: Dyspnea or tachypnea

      2. Neurological symptoms: Confusion or disorientation

      3. Petechial rash: In axilla, neck, periumbilical area, conjunctiva of lower lid, front and back of chest, shoulder

 

  • Diagnostic Criterion for Fat Embolism:

 

 

  • 1 major + 4 minor = Fat embolism

 

  • Prevention:

    • Fracture stabilization

    • Removing fat emboli from circulation by:

      • Lipolytic agents as heparin (increase serum lipase activity)

      • Hypertonic glucose (decrease FFA production)

  • Offset its effect by:

    • Dextran (expand plasma volume, reduces RBC aggregation and platelet adherence)

    • Aprotinin (protease inhibitor) – decreases platelet aggregation and serotonin release

    • Alcohol has vasodilator and lipolytic effect.

  • Treatment:

    • The aim of treatment is maintaining adequate oxygen level in the blood. If necessary, by using intermittent positive pressure ventilation. Oxygen is the only therapeutic tool of proven use.

    • It should be administered in sufficient amount to maintain arterial PO2 > 80 mm Hg. O2 toxicity (pneumonitis) is avoided by using O2 conc. below 40%.

    • Steroids are given to Avoid Pneumonitis

     

Other Options:

 

Option B. Air embolism. An air embolism occurs when air is admitted into the vascular system. It can occur iatrogenically via interventional procedures but has also been described as a complication from a blunt and penetrating trauma. The most important diagnostic criterion is the patient's history. The procedures that carry the greatest risk of air embolism are craniotomy in the sitting position, cesarean section, hip replacement, and cardiopulmonary bypass. If the patient is conscious, chest pain, dyspnea, headache, and confusion can all be symptoms. If the embolus is severe, cardiac ischemia, arrhythmias, hypotension, and cardiac arrest can ensue. 

 

Option C. Pulmonary embolism. Many PEs are likely undiagnosed. Most PEs originate as venous thromboembolisms (VTEs) in the lower extremities or pelvic veins. Less frequently, upper extremity thromboembolic events lead to PE. Major risk factors for thromboembolic events include recent immobilization, MI, CVA, surgery, and recent trauma. PE may be asymptomatic or present with sudden death. Characteristic signs and symptoms such as tachycardia, dyspnea, chest pain, hypoxemia, and shock are non-specific. 

 

Option D. DIC. Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is a hypercoagulable state that can lead to both microvascular and macrovascular clotting and compromised blood flow, ultimately resulting in multiple organ dysfunction syndrome. It typically occurs as an acute complication in patients with underlying life-threatening illnesses such as severe sepsis, hematologic malignancies, severe trauma, or placental abruption. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient presenting with fracture of femur, complaint of breathlessness after 48 hours, is highly suggestive of fat embolism.

questions.text: While examining a patient in supine position, the examiner keeps his hand below the heel of one foot and asks the patient to flex the other hip against resistance, while keeping the week leg straight. This is known as:(AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hoover’s sign

 

HOOVER TEST:

 

  • Hoover’s sign is a maneuver to separate organic from non-organic paresis of Leg.
  • Principle: Synergistic Contraction.
  • Involuntary extension of normal leg occurs with flexion of contralateral limb against resistance.
  • Test Positioning:
    • The subject relaxes in a supine position on the table while the examiner places both of the subject’s heels into their palm.
  • Action:
    • The subject is asked to perform a unilateral straight leg raise.
  • Positive Finding:
    • The inability to lift the leg may reflect a neuromuscular weakness.
    • A positive finding is also noted when the examiner does not feel increased pressure in the palm that underlies the resting leg.
    • Organic Cause: Flexion of paralyzed limb → heel of normal limb pushes the examiner’s hand.
    • Functional Weakness: Heel does not pushdown, i.e. the effort is not being transmitted.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Waddell’s test. Tests of malingering. Each test counts as +1 if +ve, 0 if –ve. This includes Superficial skin tenderness to light pinch over wide area of lumbar spine; Deep tenderness over wide area, often extending to thoracic spine, sacrum, and/or pelvis; Low back pain on axial loading of spine in standing; SLR test positive in supine, but not when seated with knee extended to test Babinski reflex; Abnormal or inconsistent neurological (motor and/or sensory) patterns; Overreaction. If 3+ points or more are there, investigate for non-organic cause.

 

Option B. O’ Donoghue’s test. Structures affected: Cervical spinal muscles and/or cervical spinal ligaments. The cervical spine of a seated patient is passively flexed, extended, laterally flexed to both sides, and rotated in both directions against patient resistance. Pain precipitated by such isometric contraction indicates cervical strain. The test is then repeated without patient resistance. Pain precipitated by passive unrestricted motion signifies cervical sprain.

 

 

O’Donoghue’s Maneuver for Knee Joint: This maneuver can be used to diagnose meniscal pathologies in the knee. With the patient in prone, the examiner flexes the knee to 90° and then rotates the tibia internally and externally twice, then fully extends the knee and repeat the rotations. Increased pain during rotation in either or both knee positions indicates a meniscal tear or joint capsule irritation. With a valgus force to a flexed and laterally rotated knee, the medial meniscus, medial collateral ligament (MCL), and ACL all may be injured, representing the O'Donoghue triad.

 

Option D. McMurray test. This test indicates tears of the middle or posterior horn of the meniscus. With the patient supine and the hip and knee fully flexed, apply a valgus force and externally rotate the tibia while extending the knee. An audible or palpable pop or snap indicates a medial meniscal tear. Lesions of the lateral meniscus are tested by applying a varus force and internally rotating the tibia during knee extension. The snap is produced as the torn fragment rides over the femoral condyle during extension. A snap in extreme flexion is indicative of a posterior horn tear; a click at 90° of flexion indicates a lesion in the middle section of the meniscus. Only 57% of meniscal root tears result in a positive McMurray test. 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

While examining a patient in supine position, the examiner keeps his hand below the heel of one foot and asks the patient to flex the other hip against resistance, while keeping the week leg straight. This is known as Hoover’s sign.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl arrives with several swellings and numerous brown rashes. Bone scans reveal heightened activity in the femur, skull, and rib areas. There are irregularities in her biochemical values. Additionally, she has a past medical record of hypothyroidism. The provided image displays an X-ray of her femur. What is the probable diagnosis from the options provided?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. McCune-Albright syndrome

 

MCCUNE ALBRIGHT SYNDROME

 

  • Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia (multiple bones involved)
  • Precocious puberty (endocrine abnormalities)
  • Cutaneous Pigmentation (café Au lait: coffee-colored spots)
  • The cafe au lait spots have characteristically irregular ragged borders (commonly called “coast of Maine” bor- ders), as opposed to the smoothly marginated borders (“coast of California”) of the spots seen in neurofibromatosis.
  • Surgical treatment by curettage + bone grafting is indicated when significant deformity or pathological fracture occurs or when significant pain exists.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Langerhans cell histiocytosis. It is the idiopathic destruction of histiocytes. The disease has characteristics of both an abnormal reactive process and a neoplastic process. It may present initially as a rash, and can disseminate and involve bone marrow, lungs, liver, spleen, lymph nodes, gastrointestinal (GI) tract, and the pituitary gland. Histologically, the primary lesion is granulomatous with an influx of eosinophils, macrophages, T cells and multinucleated cells. The Birbeck granule is the microscopic hallmark of the disorder but may not be seen in lesions of the spleen, liver, and GI tract. The rash may be distinguished by the presence of petechiae, bloody crusting, or firmly indurated nodules. Bony involvement occurs in 78% patients. Solitary osseous lesions are incidentally found and may include the skull, hip/pelvis, femur, or ribs. This bony involvement may produce bone pain. In long bones, endosteal scalloping may be responsible for a “budding appearance”.

 

 

Endosteal scalloping presenting as budding appearance

 

Option C. Neuroma with bone involvement. Morton's neuroma is one of the most common pain syndromes affecting the forefoot. It is characterized by tenderness and burning pain in the plantar surface of the forefoot, with painful paresthesias in the two affected toes. This pain syndrome is caused by perineural fibrosis of the interdigital nerves. Although the nerves between the third and fourth toes are affected most commonly, the second and third toes and, rarely, the fourth and fifth toes can be affected as well. Patients may feel like they are walking with a stone in the shoe. The pain worsens with prolonged standing or walking for long distances and is exacerbated by poorly fitting or improperly padded shoes. Morton's neuroma is associated with wearing tight, narrow-toed shoes. On physical examination, pain can be reproduced by firmly squeezing the 2 metatarsal heads together with one hand while placing firm pressure on the interdigital space with the other hand. This maneuver is known as the Mulder sign. The patient exhibits an antalgic gait in an effort to reduce weight bearing during walking.

 

 

Option D. Papillary carcinoma of thyroid. Papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) is an epithelial malignancy showing follicular cell differentiation and nuclear features. It is the most frequent thyroid neoplasm. The tumor usually appears as an irregular solid mass. One key feature is the ability to invade adjacent structures like lymphatics. About 10% patients may present with metastatic disease at initial presentation. It usually presents as an asymptomatic thyroid mass with or without enlargement of regional (cervical) lymph nodes. Hoarseness and dysphagia occur in approximately 20% cases, signaling recurrent laryngeal nerve involvement with vocal cord paralysis or tracheal compression. Nodal metastases in the lateral neck are reported in 27% patients. The examination reveals a painless hard lesion of less than 5 cm. The mass is often fixed and has irregular borders.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The presentation of several swellings and numerous brown rashes represents café Au lait spots.
  • Bone scans reveal heightened activity in the femur, skull, and rib areas.
  • There are irregularities in her biochemical values.
  • Presence of past medical history of hypothyroidism, and Shepherd crook deformity of femur in the given image, all point towards the McCune Albright Syndrome.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male with history of intermittent evening rise of temperature and weight loss has presented with a flexion deformity of the right hip. He had occasional low back ache and on examination, there was hyper reflex on knee jerk. Identify the marked structure responsible to be involved in this pathology:(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4

 

  • Mark 4 shows Psoas major muscle. 
  • This could be a case of tuberculosis of the spine most probably at the level of T12-L1 with psoas abscess. 
  • Iliopsoas muscle is the main flexor of the hip and is attached to the lesser trochanter distal to the hip joint. 
  • Therefore, any irritation to the same can lead to formation of flexion deformity at the hip. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1. Gluteus medius: It take origin from medial surface of iliac part of hip bone. It lies deep and anterior to gluteus maximus.

 

Option B. 2. Gluteus minimus takes origin from the outer surface of the ilium, specifically between the anterior and inferior gluteal lines.

 

Option C. 3. Iliacus muscles takes origin from medial surface of iliac part of hip bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

History of intermittent evening rise of temperature and weight loss with flexion deformity of the right hip, occasional low back ache and hyper reflex on knee jerk are suggestive of tuberculosis of the spine with psoas abscess.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female came with hip flexor contracture. What is the most likely test to be done in this case?(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Thomas test

 

THOMAS TEST

 

  • It is used to assess for hip flexion contracture and psoas syndrome.
  • It is especially useful when the fixed flexion deformity is masked by excessive lordosis.
  • Steps:

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allis test. The Galeazzi test, also called Allis test, is used to assess hip dislocation, specifically testing for developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) and can also be used to assess significant leg length inequality. The examination is performed with the child lying supine and their hips flexed to 45 degrees with knees flexed to 90 degrees, and feet on examining table. In this position, look for symmetry in the level of the knees. Galeazzi’s test is positive if the height of the knees is asymmetrical, and may be due to hip dislocation, DDH, congenital femoral shortening, fracture, other congenital conditions. It is also helpful in determining whether the leg length inequality is primarily from the femur or the tibia and can be used to assess leg length with knee or hip flexion contracture.

 

 

Option C. Ober test. The Ober's test evaluates a tight, contracted or inflamed Tensor Fasciae Latae (TFL) and Iliotibial band (ITB). The patient should be in side-lying with the affected side up. Bottom knee and hip should be flexed to flatten the lumbar curve. Stand behind the patient and firmly stabilize the pelvis/greater trochanter to prevent movement in any direction. Grasp the distal end of the patient’s affected leg with your other hand and flex the leg to a right angle at the knee. Extend and abduct the hip joint. Slowly lower the leg towards the table, adduct hip until motion is restricted. Ensure that the hip does not internally rotate and flex during the test and the pelvis must be stabilized. As allowing the thigh to drop in flexion and internal rotation would 'give in' to the tight TFL and not accurately test the length. If the ITB is normal, the leg will adduct with the thigh dropping down slightly below the horizontal, the test is called negative. If the ITB is tight, the leg would remain in the abducted position and the patient would experience lateral knee pain, the test is called positive.

 

 

Option D. Trendelenburg test. The aim of Trendelenburg’s test is to assess the strength of the hip abductors, specifically the gluteus medius and minimus. It is done when a patient complains of a limp, or hip pain or as part of a normal physical examination assessing gait. If the patient is comfortable to stand alone, stand behind the patient. Alternatively, stand in front of the patient, with their forearms positioned on yours to support them. Ask the patient to lift each foot in turn off the ground. When the patient lifts their right foot, the left hip abductors are being tested. When the patient lifts their left foot, the right hip abductors are being tested. Position your hands on the patient’s iliac crests. Observe carefully if the hip on the unsupported side lifts or droops. If the patient is using your arms for support, you will feel them pressing down on one of your arms if their hip abductors are unable to support their weight. A positive Trendelenburg’s sign (pathological) involves sagging of the pelvis on the unsupported side due to the abductor muscles failing to stabilise the hip towards the weight-bearing femur.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Thomas test is used to assess the hip flexor contracture.

questions.text: A patient presents with tear in the anteroinferior aspect of the glenoid capsule and labrum. Identify the lesion. (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Bankart’s lesion

 

BANKART’S LESION

 

  • In 1938, Bankart published his classic paper in which he recognized two types of acute dislocations.
  • In the first type, the humeral head is forced through the capsule, where it is the weakest, generally anteriorly and inferiorly in the interval between the lower border of the subscapularis and the long head of the triceps muscle.
  • In the second type, the humeral head is forced anteriorly out of the glenoid cavity and tears the fibrocartilaginous labrum from almost the entire anterior half of the rim of the glenoid cavity, and also the capsule and periosteum from the anterior surface of the neck of the scapula.
  • This traumatic detachment of the glenoid labrum has been called the Bankart lesion.
  • Bankart lesion is the most commonly observed pathological lesion in recurrent subluxation or dislocation of the shoulder.

 

 

  • This result in anterior instability of the shoulder joint due to the loss of the normal mechanisms, such as the block effect of the labrum, concavity compression mechanism of the rotator cuff, and function of the inferior glenohumeral ligament.
  • Lesions of the glenoid labrum are most commonly the result of traumatic anterior shoulder dislocation with the shoulder in external rotation and abduction.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Hill-Sachs lesion. A Hill-Sachs lesion is an osseous defect or "dent" of the postero-supero-lateral humeral head that occurs in association with anterior instability or dislocation of the glenohumeral joint. It is often associated with a Bankart lesion of the glenoid. This lesion is caused by an anterior shoulder dislocation which causes a humeral head impression fracture. The posterolateral aspect of the humeral head impacts on the anterior glenoid in the dislocated position, causing shoulder instability. If these lesions involve more than 20% of the glenoid, they can result in recurrent instability despite having an excellent soft-tissue repair. They are also called as impression fractures.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • A tear in the anteroinferior aspect of the glenoid capsule and labrum is called Bankart’s lesion, which is caused due to traumatic anterior dislocation of the shoulder.

questions.text: Hyperextension at MCP joint and flexion at IP joint occurs due to involvement of which muscle?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lumbricals and interossei

 

  • The Lumbricals (+ interossei) paralysis causes claw hand (MCP hyperextension and IP joint flexion).

 

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Hyperextension of the MCP joint and flexion of the IP joint is seen in the claw hand deformity due to weakness of the intrinsic muscles of the hand i.e., the lumbricals and the interossei.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy was brought by his parents to the clinic complaining of pain in his right hip. An X-ray of his pelvis was taken and is shown below. What is your diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Osteogenesis imperfecta

 

The X-ray reveals a sub capital femoral neck fracture along with suspected multiple fractures in the greater trochanter, which are indicative of osteogenesis imperfecta. This condition is characterized by generalized osteopenia, thinning of long bones, fractures at various stages of healing, vertebral compression, and spinal deformity. The abnormal synthesis and structural defects of type I collagen lead to these bone abnormalities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteoporosis - Osteoporosis is a condition where bones become weak and brittle due to loss of bone mass. While it can also cause fractures, it typically affects older adults and doesn't usually present with multiple fractures in childhood.

 

Option B. Osteopetrosis - Osteopetrosis, or marble bone disease, is a rare genetic disorder where bones become abnormally dense and hard. This would lead to increased bone density on X-ray, not decreased density.

 

Option D. Osteopoikilosis - Osteopoikilosis is a benign condition characterized by multiple small, round spots of increased bone density on X-rays. It doesn't cause fractures or generalized bone fragility.

 

Educational Objective:


Osteogenesis imperfecta involves generalized bone fragility due to defective type I collagen, leading to frequent fractures and skeletal deformities

questions.text: A patient who used to workout regularly at the gym, gradually developed pain in the hip which is aggravated while squatting. He gives history of regular steroid and creatine use over last six months. There is flattening of femoral head and subchondral cysts were seen on X-ray. What is the likely diagnosis?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) AVN of hip

 

AVASCULAR NECROSIS

 

  • Avascular necrosis (AVN) is the cellular death of components of bone due to impaired blood supply.
  • It affects anterolateral aspect of femoral head.
  • Etiopathogenesis: Idiopathic (most common) – called as Chandeliers disease.
  • Causes:

 

 

  • Clinical Features:
    • Age 20-50 years with slight male preponderance (Young Male).
    • Bilateral in 50% of idiopathic cases, and 80% of steroid-induced cases.
    • Decreased range of motion especially internal rotation followed by abduction – characteristic feature
    • A characteristic sign is a tendency for hip to twist into external rotation during passive flexion - ‘Sectoral sign’ – with the hip extended, internal rotation is almost full but with hip flexed, it is grossly restricted – due to a sector of femoral head being involved in AVN.
    • X-rays Sclerosed area shows area of necrosis; Crescent sign – Crescentric defect in subchondral area.

 

 

  • MRI is the investigation of choice – Double line sign is seen.
  • T1: Reduced intensity or irregular outline of head.
  • T2: High signal intensity called as double line sign.

 

 

  • Classification system:
    • University at Pennsylvania system:
      • Mild AVN: < 15% of Femoral head involved
      • Moderate AVN: 15-30% of Femoral head involved
      • Severe AVN: >30% of Femoral head involved
         
  • Treatment:
    • Early stages: protected weight-bearing.
    • Pre-collapse stage: Core decompression to decrease intraosseous pressure in femoral head (Normal Intraosseous pressure = 10-20 mm Hg; 3-4 times in AVN). Drill holes are made in femoral head. This procedure also opens the channels for vascular ingrowths and it is also supplemented with bone grafting (Vascular or nonvascular) or electrical stimulation or bone morphogenic proteins.

 

 

  • Muscle Pedicle graft: Quadratus femoris (Meyers graft)/Tensor fascia lata graft (Joshi’s graft) can be fixed in femoral head to augment vascularity.

 

 

  • Rotational osteotomy: To get the intact part of femoral head in acetabulum weight-bearing area (anterolateral aspect of femur head) this is an extensive procedure requiring vascular repair along with it.

 

 

  • Arthritis/Collapse of femoral head: Total hip replacement one of the very commonly done procedure as most patients present at stage of arthritis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. TB of hip. Initial focus is in the acetabulum. The majority of cases of hip TB presents as painful, restricted movements of the hip, and a limp. It is secondary to primary pathology in lungs, lymph nodes or any of the viscera. Disease usually starts during first three decades. Depending upon the extent of involvement, there can be deformity, shortening of the limb, swelling, pathological dislocations, and sinuses.

 

 

 

Wandering acetabulum

 

 

Stage of arthritis

 

Treatment involved Girdlestone excision arthroplasty/arthrodesis/THR.

 

 

Stage I and II are treated with ATT and traction. If required, joint debridement/synovectomy can be done. Stage III, IV and V are treated with ATT and joint replacement/arthrodesis/osteotomy/excision arthroplasty.

 

Option C. Fracture neck of femur. Femoral neck fractures are a specific type of intracapsular hip fracture. Femoral neck fractures are associated with low energy falls in the elderly. In younger patients, the cause is usually secondary to high-energy trauma such as a substantial height or motor vehicle accidents. Risk factors for femoral neck fractures include female gender, decreased mobility, and low bone density. Displaced fractures of the femoral neck put the blood supply at risk, usually tearing the ascending cervical branches. This may compromise the healing ability of the fracture, inevitably causing non-union or osteonecrosis. The patient will complain of pain with a decreased range of motion of the hip. In non-displaced fractures, there may be no deformity. However, displaced fractures may present with a shortened and externally rotated lower limb. MRI is more sensitive (100% sensitivity) and specific for diagnosis.

 

 

 

 

Garden’s classification

 

Treatment is done by closed reduction and internal fixation in age < 65 years. In age > 65 years, hemiarthroplasty is done if there is a pre-existing arthritis. If there is no pre-existing arthritis, total hip replacement is done.

 

Option D. Osteomalacia. Often referred to as "soft bone disease," is a metabolic bone disorder characterized by the inadequate mineralization of bone tissue. There is adult onset of bone softening and muscle weakness. This condition results from a deficiency in vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate, weakening and softening bones. Symptoms are non-specific and may include low back and thigh pain, proximal muscle weakness and wasting; Myalgia and arthralgia; Muscle spasms; waddling gait; Spinal, limb, or pelvic deformities; Aching bone pain aggravated by activity and weight-bearing; Increased falls; Hypocalcemic seizures or tetany. Triradiate pelvis, protrusion acetabular (acetabulum protrudes into pelvis due to bone softening. When bilateral, it is called as Otto Pelvis), pseudofracture are seen on x-ray. There is waddling gait due to muscular weakness.

 

 

A. Triradiate pelvis; B. Protrusio acetabuli

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Regular steroid is the major risk factor for development of avascular necrosis of the hip.
  • Flattening of femoral head on radiograph is also seen in the avascular necrosis of hip.

choices.text: Chemotherapy is the treatment of choice

questions.text: Which statement is incorrect about the pathology shown?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chemotherapy is the treatment of choice

 

The given X-ray shows eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region with distinct margins with soap bubble appearance indicative of Giant cell tumour (GCT). Treatment of GCT includes Curettage or Excision with bone grafting.

 

GIANT-CELL TUMOR (OSTEOCLASTOMA)

 

  • It is bone lesion of uncertain origin, most commonly seen in distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus and distal radius.
  • Most commonly seen in 20-40 years of age, after epiphyseal fusion.
  • Histology: Multinucleated giant cells are seen on a background of stromal cells with little or no visible intercellular tissue. The nuclei of the mononuclear cells are identical to the nuclei of giant cells - a feature that helps to distinguish giant cell tumor from other tumors that may contain giant cells.

 

Clinical Features

 

  • Most commonly presents with pain, with or without swelling.
  • Pathological fracture occurs in 10-15% of cases.
  • Pulmonary metastasis occurs in 4% of cases, but they usually regress spontaneously.

 

Radiological Features

 

  • Eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region with distinct margins, bounded by subchondral bone plate, with soap bubble appearance.

 

Treatment

 

  • Curettage and ‘stripping’ of the cavity, followed by swabbing with hydrogen peroxide or by the application of liquid nitrogen.
  • More aggressive tumors and recurrent lesions: Excision followed by bone grafting.

 

Educational Objective

 

Giant Cell Tumor (GCT) of bone typically manifests as an eccentric lytic lesion in the epiphyseal region of long bones with distinct margins. The mainstay of treatment for GCT is surgical intervention, either through curettage or excision followed by bone grafting, rather than chemotherapy. This surgical approach helps ensure complete removal of the tumor and helps prevent recurrence.

choices.text: Head neck, thoracic and abdominal triage

questions.text: What are the different levels of triage in emergency care? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Immediate, delayed, and minimal triage

 

The different levels of triage in emergency care are immediate, delayed, and minimal triage.

 

Immediate triage (red tag) is the highest priority and is given to patients who have life-threatening injuries or illnesses that require prompt medical attention. Examples of immediate triage include patients with severe bleeding or difficulty breathing.

 

Delayed triage (yellow tag) is given to patients who have injuries or illnesses that are not immediately life-threatening but require medical attention. Examples of delayed triage include patients with open fractures or moderate burns.

 

Minimal triage (green tag) is given to patients who have minor injuries or illnesses that do not require immediate medical attention. Examples of minimal triage include patients with minor cuts or bruises.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triage helps to ensure that patients receive the appropriate level of care based on their condition and the resources available. By prioritizing patients based on the severity of their injuries or illnesses, emergency medical personnel can provide the best possible care to the greatest number of patients in a disaster or emergency situation.

questions.text: First deformity corrected in CTEV is:(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cavus

 

CLUB FOOT/CONGENITAL TALIPES EQUINO VARUS (CTEV)

 

  • Incidence: 1:1000 live births
  • M:F – 2.5:1
  • 50% are bilateral
  • In its most characteristic form, there are four elements of deformity – Equinus of ankle, inversion of foot, adduction of fore foot and medial rotation of tibia.

 

 

  • Conservative Management:

 

 

  • First cast in CTEV is applied in supination to correct cavus.
  • Subsequently in kites, one deformity is corrected at a time, adduction first then varus and then equinus (CAVE).
  • In ponsetti method, adduction and Varus are corrected simultaneously and Equinus is corrected at last.
  • Thus in Kites method, one deformity is corrected at a time but in ponsetti adduction and varus are corrected simultaneously, equinus is corrected at end in both.

 

 

Sequential correction

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Forefoot adduction. This is corrected after the correction of the cavus deformity of the foot. (CAVE)

 

Option C. Varus. This is corrected after the correction of cavus followed by forefoot adduction. (CAVE)

 

Option D. Equinus. This is corrected in the last because it is the most resistant deformity. (CAVE)

questions.text: In a village, it is observed that several farmers have crossed gait and use a stick for support to stand up and walk. Due to poor yield from farms, they consume meals containing rice and pulses only. Supplementing their diet with which of the following vitamins could have prevented this? [NEET PG 2023]

The given clinical scenario points to diagnosis of neurolathyrism. Vitamin C is beneficial in cases of lathyrism.

 

Lathyrism is of two types:

 

  • Neurolathyrism: In human beings

  • Osteolathyrism (Odoratism): In animals

     

Neurolathyrism is caused by eating the pulse ‘Khesari Dal (Lathyrus sativus)’. Diets containing over 30% of this dal consumed over a period of 2 - 6 months result in neurolathyrism

 

Toxin: present in lathyrus seeds is ‘Beta oxalyl amino alanine’ (BOAA)

questions.text: Match the Eponym with their fractures.(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1-c, 2-d, 3-a, 4-e

 

  • The correct description of the given fractures are:

 

 

COMMON FRACTURE EPONYMS

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

1. Pilon’s fracture: It is the intra-articular comminuted fracture of the distal tibia. It is also known as Plafond fracture, Tibia Plafond fracture, Distal Tibial Explosion fracture. The high energy axial compression force if the tibia acts as a pestle, driving vertically into the talus.

 

 

2. Runner’s fracture: It is the fracture of lower end of the fibula. They are usually the stress fracture, commonly seen in runners.

 

 

3. Cotton’s fracture: It is the trimalleolar fracture in the ankle i.e., there is involvement of medial and lateral malleoli, and posterior aspect of the tibial plafond (also called as posterior malleolus). This is a more unstable fracture and may be associated with ligamentous injury.

 

 

4. Chauffer’s fracture: It is an intra-articular oblique fracture of the styloid process of the radius. It is sustained from a direct trauma like a blow to the back of the wrist or from forced dorsiflexion and abduction of the wrist.

questions.text:
Which of the following statement/s is/are true regarding open fracture?(INICET MAY 2021)

 

  1. Compartment syndrome is rare.
  2. Immediate debridement should be done.
  3. Tibia is the most common long bone involved.
  4. Multiple fractures are uncommon.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) I, II & III are correct

 

I. Compartment syndrome is rare: True

 

  • In open fractures, the fascia may be disrupted, which reduces the risk of rising compartment pressure.

  • However, compartment syndrome can still occur, especially in high-energy injuries, so it is not impossible, but it is less common compared to closed fractures.

 

II. Immediate debridement should be done: True

 

  • Early and thorough surgical debridement is the cornerstone of open fracture management to reduce infection risk.

  • Ideally performed within 6–8 hours, though recent evidence suggests that a short delay may not significantly change infection rates if antibiotics are given promptly.

 

III. Tibia is the most common long bone involved: True

 

  • The tibia is the most commonly involved long bone in open fractures due to its subcutaneous location (minimal soft tissue coverage).

  • Therefore, it’s more vulnerable to open injuries, especially in road traffic accidents.

 

IV. Multiple fractures are uncommon: False

  • Multiple fractures are actually common, particularly in high-energy trauma like road traffic accidents, falls from height, or blast injuries.

  • Open fractures often occur as part of polytrauma.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In open fracture, compartment syndrome is a rare entity as the fracture communicates with the surrounding atmosphere, preventing an increase in the compartment pressure.
  • These fractures need immediate irrigation with antibiotics and debridement of the wound.
  • Tibia is the most common site for open fractures after phalanges.

questions.text: Which of the following condition will cause intermittent breaking of long bones in a child? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Osteogenesis Imperfecta

 

OSTEOGENESIS IMPERFECTA

 

  • It is a genetic disorder of connective tissue determined by quantitative and qualitative defect in type I collagen formation.
  • There is alteration in the structural integrity, or a reduction in the total amount of type I collagen.
  • Most common cause of multiple fractures in childhood.
  • It is also known as Lobstein-Vrolik brittle bone disease.
  • It is inherited from a parent in autosomal dominant (AD) fashion, or may occur as spontaneous mutation, or, rarely as autosomal recessive (AR) trait.
  • Clinical features:
    • The defining clinical feature is osteopenia, causing repeated propensity to fracture, generally after minor trauma and often without much pain or swelling.
    • According to the severity of disease, fractures may occur in uterus, at birth, or after birth prior to or after walking age.
    • Lower limb fractures are more common than upper limb.
    • Femur is commonest bone fractured followed by tibia.
    • Frequency of fractures decline sharply after adolescence or puberty, although it may rise again in postmenopausal (climacteric) women.
    • Hyperlaxity of ligaments, with resultant hypermobility of joint is common.
    • Rarely recurrent dislocation of patella, radial head and hip joint dislocation and DDH can occur.
    • Blue/gray sclera due to uveal pigment visible through thin collagen layer.
    • Deafness due to otosclerosis/pressure on auditory nerve
    • Dentinogenesis imperfect/crumbling of teeth i.e., deciduous and permanent teeth break easily and become prone to carries. Lower incisors severely affected.
    • Skin becomes thin and translucent. Subcutaneous hemorrhages may occur.
    • Muscles are hypotonic due to multiple fractures and deformities.
       
  • Prenatal diagnosis: Abnormal Pro a chain
  • Radiological features:
    • Wormian bones (detached portions of primary ossification centers of adjacent membrane bones) are seen in skull X-ray. It should be more than 10 in number, measure at least 6 × 4 mm, and arranged in mosaic pattern.
    • Ring-shaped epiphysis is seen
    • Skeleton: White crumpled-bone shaped not maintained

 

 

  • Classification: SILLENCE classification
  • Treatment: 
    • Bisphosphonates to decrease osteoclastic bone resorption
    • Ideal treatment: replace COLIAI or COLIA2 gene.
       
  • SOFIELD MILLER surgery (SEEKH KEBAB surgery)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Achondroplasia. It is a primary defect of endochondral bone formation. Autosomal dominant but 80% are spontaneous mutations. It is the effect of excessive growth hormone on the mature skeleton. Paternal age >36 year is linked with new mutation. It is most common form of disproportionate dwarfism. Disproportionate rhizomelic micromelia is most severe in proximal limbs. Trunk height is be normal, but arm span and standing height are diminished. Skull is large with prominent forehead (frontal bossing), saddle-shaped nose (flat and depressed nasal bridge), small maxilla, prominent mandibles and normal dentition. The patients have normal intelligence, trident hand (separation between middle and ring fingers) and starfish hand (middle finger shorter). The vertebrae shows short interpedicular distance, bullet shape. The pelvis appears like a champagne glass (pelvic width > depth). Hooked vertebra are seen.

 

 

 

Option B. Marfan syndrome. It is the Fibrillin 1 defect. There is a disproportionate increase in the height. The limbs are long and there is arachnodactyly (fingers and hand are long and have spider-like appearance). Scoliosis, Pectus excavatum/Pectus carinatum, Hyperlaxity, High-arched palate, Pes planus, and Hammer toes are seen. Early OA is a feature. Ghent criterion is used for diagnosis of Marfan syndrome.

 

 

Option D. Cretinism. Cretinism is a condition of severely stunted physical and mental growth due to untreated congenital deficiency of thyroid hormones (congenital hypothyroidism). Congenital hypothyroidism can be endemic, genetic, or sporadic. Sporadic and genetic cretinism results from abnormal development, or function of the foetal thyroid gland. Cretinism has been almost completely eliminated in developed countries by early diagnosis by newborn screening schemes and iodine supplementation programs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Intermittent breaking of long bones in children is a feature of osteogenesis imperfecta.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents with headaches for 6 months. She has been taking analgesics regularly. The headache recently increased in severity for 3 days but was reduced on stopping the analgesic. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Medication overuse headache

 

Medication overuse headache (MOH) occurs in individuals who frequently use headache medications. The patient in this case has been experiencing headaches for six months and has been regularly using analgesics. The key indicator of MOH is the worsening of headaches with continued use of medication and improvement upon stopping the medication. This aligns with the patient's experience of increased headache severity for three days, which reduced once the analgesics were stopped.

 

MOH develops as a result of the brain becoming sensitized to the medication, leading to a rebound effect. This is a well-recognized phenomenon where the headache itself is caused by the frequent use of headache relief medication, leading to a cycle of medication use and headache.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tension headache: Tension headaches are typically relieved by analgesics, not worsened. These headaches are often characterized by a feeling of a tight band around the head and can be managed effectively with over-the-counter pain relief medications. 

 

  • Acute Treatment: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) or paracetamol are used to relieve pain.
  • Chronic Treatment: Tricyclic antidepressants, such as amitriptyline, are employed to manage chronic symptoms and reduce the recurrence of headaches.

 

Option C. Chronic migraine: Chronic migraines are managed with both acute treatments for individual attacks and preventive treatments to reduce the frequency and severity of the headaches. While chronic migraines can be debilitating, they generally improve with proper prophylaxis and do not worsen with the use of analgesics.

 

  • Treatment options include propranolol, topiramate, valproate, and monoclonal antibodies against CGRP (calcitonin gene-related peptide), such as erenumab. These are used to reduce the frequency and severity of migraine attacks.

 

Option D. Cluster headache: Cluster headaches are severe, unilateral headaches that are treated with high-flow oxygen and subcutaneous sumatriptan during acute attacks. Preventive treatments include medications like verapamil. Analgesics are not typically the first-line treatment for cluster headaches and their use does not generally lead to worsening of the condition.

 

  • Acute Treatment: High-flow 100% oxygen inhalation or subcutaneous sumatriptan injections are recommended to alleviate the intense pain of acute cluster headache attacks.
  • Chronic Treatment: Verapamil is used for long-term management to prevent the frequency and intensity of cluster headache episodes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medication overuse headache is characterized by the worsening of headaches due to frequent use of headache medications, and improvement upon cessation of the medication. This phenomenon highlights the importance of managing headache disorders with appropriate treatments and avoiding overuse of analgesics.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents to the orthopedic clinic with persistent left knee pain and swelling for the past three months. He describes the pain as constant and worsening, even occurring at rest. There is no history of trauma. Physical examination reveals a swollen and tender distal femur with limited range of motion due to pain. An X-ray shows a sunburst pattern and periosteal reaction consistent with an aggressive bone lesion. The tumor is surgically resected, and the gross specimen reveals a gritty, gray-white mass with areas of necrosis and hemorrhage. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Osteosarcoma

 

The combination of the patient's age, clinical presentation (persistent pain, swelling, and limited range of motion), radiographic findings (sunburst pattern and periosteal reaction), and gross specimen description (gritty, gray-white mass with necrosis and hemorrhage) strongly points towards osteosarcoma.

 

Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant bone tumor, typically affecting adolescents and young adults. It often presents with pain, swelling, and limited range of motion in the affected bone. Radiographically, it is characterized by a destructive lesion with a sunburst pattern and periosteal reaction. The gross appearance of the tumor is consistent with a gritty, gray-white mass with areas of necrosis and hemorrhage.

 

Treatment: The primary treatment for osteosarcoma is a combination of chemotherapy and surgery. Chemotherapy is given before and after surgery to shrink the tumor and kill any remaining cancer cells. Surgery typically involves removing the affected bone and replacing it with a prosthesis or bone graft. In some cases, radiation therapy may also be used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fibrous dysplasia: A benign bone condition where normal bone is replaced with fibrous tissue, leading to deformity and fracture. Radiographically, it appears as a ground-glass lesion without aggressive periosteal reaction, unlike osteosarcoma.

 

Option C. Aneurysmal bone cyst: A benign, blood-filled bone lesion that presents with a "blow-out" or soap bubble appearance on imaging. It does not have the sunburst pattern or the malignant features associated with osteosarcoma.

 

Option D. Non-ossifying fibroma: A benign, fibrous bone lesion commonly found in children, often presenting as an incidental finding on X-rays with a lytic, well-defined appearance. It does not exhibit aggressive growth or the gritty, necrotic gross pathology seen in osteosarcoma.

 

Educational Objective:


Osteosarcoma is a primary malignant bone tumor common in adolescents, presenting with aggressive radiographic features and characteristic gross pathology. Early recognition and timely intervention are crucial to prevent metastatic spread and improve survival outcomes.

questions.text: Which of the following substances can be used for new bone formation in cases of non-union fracture?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bone morphogenetic protein

 

PROPERTIES OF GRAFT MATERIALS

 

 

 

  • Atrophic non union (absent callus, poor bone biology, lack of blood supply) are fixed by internal fixation with biologic stimulation.
  • Biologic stimulation is done with bone graft and bone morphogenetic protein (BMP).
  • Although the gold standard in nonunion therapy is the transplantation of autologous bone graft, missing bone regeneration subsequent to transplantation of autologous bone graft poses a serious disadvantage for the patients. Therefore, in the last few years, this therapy was combined with the application of bone morphogenetic protein-7 (BMP-7).
  • Use of BMP-7 is approved for tibial non-unions.
  • BMP-2 is approved for 1 level degenerative disk disease in spinal fusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Calcium phosphate. Calcium Phosphate Cement is a useful bone substitute for benign bone tumor surgery. It provides excellent osteoconductivity and long-lasting stability without internal fixation.

 

Option B. Caclium sulphate. Calcium sulfate is a synthetic ceramic bone graft substitutes which has an osteoconductive property. It is a bio-inert material which gets resorbed over a period of weeks and fibrovascular tissue takes its place which eventually allows neovascularisation and bone formation within the area. Use of calcium sulfate as a bone graft substitutes avoids the complications and morbidity associated with autograft like infection.

 

Option C. PMMA. Polymethylmethacrylate is one of the most enduring materials in orthopaedic surgery. It has a central role in the success of total joint replacement and is also used in newer techniques such as percutaneous vertebroplasty and kyphoplasty.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BMP helps in bone formation and repair. Thus, for the union of non-united fractures by surgery, it is used as an autograft material.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with bitemporal hemianopia. CT is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Craniopharyngioma

 

Explanation:

 

A calcified lesion in the suprasellar region suggests craniopharyngioma. It is derived from Rathke's pouch.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Pituitary adenomas are seen in the sellar region in adults. Macroadenomas are seen as snowman or figure of eight appearance.

 

 

Option B: Meningioma is a supratentorial tumor, mainly in the parasagittal region. A classical Dural tail is seen.

 

 

Option D: Oligodendroglioma is exclusively found in the cerebral hemispheres, most commonly in the frontal lobes. Up to 90% of oligodendrogliomas contain visible calcification on CT.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Craniopharyngioma should be considered in pediatric patients presenting with visual disturbances and evidence of a calcified mass in the suprasellar region on imaging. This diagnosis is important due to the potential impact on the optic pathways and pituitary gland function, requiring careful management.

 

Reference– Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 742

questions.text: A child presents with right hip pain and difficulty walking. An X-ray of the hip, shown below, reveals certain abnormalities. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Osteopetrosis

 

Explanation:
 

The clinical presentation of hip pain and difficulty walking, along with the X-ray findings of sclerosis and thickening of bones (increased radiographic density), strongly suggests osteopetrosis. Osteopetrosis, also known as "marble bone disease," is characterized by defective bone resorption due to impaired osteoclast function, leading to bones that are denser yet more fragile. This increased bone density is a hallmark of the condition and can paradoxically make the bones more prone to fractures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Osteopoikilosis - This condition typically presents with numerous small, round, sclerotic bone lesions scattered throughout the skeleton, rather than generalized bone sclerosis.

 

Option C. Osteoporosis - Usually presents with decreased bone density, thinning cortices, and increased fracture risk, not increased bone density.

 

Option D. Osteogenesis imperfecta - Known for generalized osteopenia, frequent fractures, and bone deformities due to defective type I collagen, not increased bone density.

 

Educational Objective:


Osteopetrosis is marked by increased bone density and thickness due to defective bone resorption, often leading to pain and fractures despite the denser appearance of bones.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the given image? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aberrant right subclavian artery

 

The CT scan image provided shows an anatomical variant where there is an extra vessel coursing behind the esophagus towards the right side. Normally, there are three major arch arteries visible at this level. However, in this image, an additional vessel is seen, which is characteristic of an aberrant right subclavian artery.

 

The aberrant right subclavian artery is an anatomical variation where the right subclavian artery arises as the fourth branch of the aortic arch and passes posterior to the esophagus. This can lead to a condition known as dysphagia lusoria, where the esophagus is compressed by the artery, causing difficulty in swallowing (dysphagia).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right sided aortic arch: This condition involves the aortic arch itself being positioned on the right side, which is not indicated by the presence of an extra vessel behind the esophagus in this image.

 

Option C. Tracheal diverticulum: A tracheal diverticulum would appear as an air-filled outpouching from the trachea. The image does not show any such outpouching or abnormality of the trachea.

 

Option D. Esophageal duplication: This is a rare congenital condition where a duplicated segment of the esophagus is present. The image does not show an additional lumen or any signs indicative of esophageal duplication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An aberrant right subclavian artery is an anatomical variant where the artery arises as the fourth branch of the aortic arch and courses posterior to the esophagus, often leading to dysphagia lusoria due to esophageal compression.

questions.text: Painful arc syndrome is seen in:(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mid-abduction

 

IMPINGEMENT SYNDROME

 

  • It is soft tissues entrapment.
  • Tendinitis of the rotator cuff is the major cause of a painful shoulder.
  • The rotator cuff consists of the tendons of the supraspinatus, infraspinatus, subscapularis, and teres minor muscles, and inserts on the humeral tuberosity.
  • The supraspinatus tendon is the most often affected, probably because of its repeated impingement between the humeral head and the undersurface of the anterior third of the acromion and coracoacromial ligament above as well as the reduction in its blood supply that occurs with abduction of the arm. This phenomenon is described as impingement syndrome.
  • The process begins with edema and hemorrhage of the rotator cuff which evolves to fibrotic thickening and eventually to rotator cuff degeneration with tendon tears and bone spurs.
  • Subacromial bursitis also accompanies this syndrome.
  • Symptoms usually appear after injury or overuse, especially with activities involving elevation of the arm with some degree of forward flexion.
  • Impingement syndrome occurs in persons participating in baseball, tennis, swimming, or occupations that require repeated elevation of the arm.
  • Severe pain is experienced when the arm is actively abducted into an overhead position. The arc between 60° and 120° (mid-range abduction) is especially painful. This is also described as “painful arc syndrome”.
  • NSAIDs, local glucocorticoid injection, and physical therapy may relieve symptoms.
  • Surgical decompression of the subacromial space may be necessary in patient refractory to conservative treatment

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Initial abduction: Incorrect, as the pain typically does not start at the beginning of abduction but becomes noticeable as the arm reaches mid-range.

 

Option C. Full range of abduction: Incorrect, although the entire range might be uncomfortable, the specific "painful arc" is usually observed in the mid-range.

 

Option D. Overhead abduction: Incorrect, as the term "painful arc syndrome" specifically refers to pain experienced in the mid-range of abduction, not necessarily when the arm is fully overhead.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Painful arc syndrome, a clinical manifestation of impingement syndrome, is observed during mid-range shoulder abduction, typically between 60° and 120°. This condition is often seen in individuals engaging in activities that involve repeated arm elevation, and management may include NSAIDs, corticosteroid injections, physical therapy, or, in refractory cases, surgical intervention to decompress the subacromial space.

questions.text: Counter force brace is used for:(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tennis elbow

 

TENNIS ELBOW OR LATERAL EPICONDYLITIS

 

  • Any occupation that requires repeated/sustained wrist extension or repeated pinching/grasping can result in lateral epicondylitis; the condition is, therefore, not limited to sports-related (i.e., one-handed tennis back hand) injuries.
  • Classically, this is tendonitis of the extensor carpi radialis brevis (common extensor origin) tendon at the lateral humeral epicondyle, but can affect the extensor carpi radialis longus at the supracondylar line.

 

 

  • It may result in small tears, fibrocartilaginous metaplasia, microscopic calcification and painful vascular reaction in tendon fibers close to lateral epicondyle (degenerative changes with angiofibroblastic proliferation).
  • Clinical Features:
    • Localized tenderness at or just below lateral epicondyle.
    • Pain can be reproduced by passively stretching the extensor radialis brevis. This is done by extending the elbow, pronating the forearm and then passively flexing the wrist or active extension of wrist against resistance can produce pain (Cozen’s test).

 

 

  • Pain with resisted extension (as seen in the Chair test) or with activities such as wrist dorsiflexion or gripping activities is typically reported by the patient.
     

  • Management:
    • Usual treatment includes work modification to minimize contributing activities with the focus on a better anthropomorphic match between the user and their work environment in contrast to a one-size-fits-all design strategy.
    • Acute pain can be treated with anti-inflammatories, cold pack massage over the extensor origin, rest, a wrist extensor strengthening regimen, or use of a counterforce (“tennis elbow”) brace.
    • The proposed mechanism for this brace is the dissipation of the forces away from the injured tissue to the surrounding noninjured area. 
    • This type of brace can be both a rehabilitative and a functional orthosis.

 

 

  • Chronic lateral epicondylitis treatment strategies in the context of employment are more controversial.
     

  • Some common treatments include steroid injection, platelet rich plasma, dry needling/trigger point injections, physical therapy to include isometric and concentric exercises, and stretches.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Wrist drop. For wrist drop due to radial nerve palsy, a dynamic cock-up splint is given.

 

 

Option C. Foot drop. For foot drop, an AFO or ankle-foot orthosis or leaf brace is given.

 

 

Option D. Ankle sprain. For ankle sprain, an adjustable ankle brace is given.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Counter force brace is used for the rehabilitation of tennis elbow.
  • This brace dissipates the forces away from the injured tissue to the surrounding non-injured area.

choices.text: Can be used for screening mammographically undetectable or clinically non palpable breast mass
Useful in young females with dense breast
Differentiates between solid and Cystic lesions in the Breast

questions.text: Which of the following isn't considered a benefit of USG compared to Mammography?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Can be used for screening mammographically undetectable clinically non palpable breast mass

 

Ultrasound has no role in detecting non-palpable breast cancers.

 

Ultrasound is particularly useful in young women with dense breasts in whom mammograms are difficult to interpret, and in distinguishing cysts from solid lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Useful in young females with dense breast: Ultrasound is indeed beneficial in young women with dense breast tissue where mammograms can be harder to interpret due to the denseness of the tissue obscuring the view of potential abnormalities.

 

Option C. Differentiates between solid and Cystic lesions in the Breast: Ultrasound is particularly effective in distinguishing between solid and cystic lesions within the breast. This ability is crucial for determining the nature of a breast mass and guiding further diagnostic and treatment actions.

 

Option D. Guided biopsy can be done: Ultrasound-guided biopsy is a well-established procedure that uses ultrasound imaging to guide the needle to the precise location of the abnormal tissue in the breast for sampling. This is particularly useful for targeting lesions that are visible on ultrasound but not palpable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ultrasound should not be considered a standalone screening tool for non-palpable breast masses or those not detected by mammography. However, it is invaluable in specific scenarios such as evaluating women with dense breasts, distinguishing between cystic and solid breast lesions, and facilitating guided biopsies.

choices.text: C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers
A fibers are more sensitive to hypoxia than B fibers
A fibers are more susceptible to pressure changes than C fibers
A fibers are more susceptible to hypoxia than C fibers

questions.text: A person after sleeping overnight with the arm under his head now experiences paresis but no numbness in the morning. Which of the following is the best explanation for it?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. A fibers are more susceptible to pressure changes than C fibers

 

Explanation

 

In the above scenario, the patient has developed paresis (partial paralysis) but the pain sensation is intact (no numbness) suggests A fibers involvement as they carry motor, touch, and pressure sensations are most sensitive to pressure changes/compression.

 

A fibers are myelinated nerve fibers responsible for transmitting signals related to touch, pressure, and proprioception (the sense of one's body position). C fibers, on the other hand, are unmyelinated and transmit slower pain signals. While both types of fibers can be affected by pressure, A fibers are more vulnerable to damage from sustained pressure than C fibers, which are more resistant to compression.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers. - Incorrect. C fibers are unmyelinated and relatively more resistant to pressure compared to myelinated A fibers.

 

Option B. A fibers are more sensitive to hypoxia than B fibers. - Not relevant to the scenario, as the issue is related to mechanical pressure, not oxygen deprivation.

 

Option D. A fibers are more susceptible to hypoxia than C fibers. - Also not relevant to the given scenario, focusing on hypoxia instead of the impact of mechanical pressure or compression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Relative susceptibility -

choices.text: Biologic agents are first-line therapy and should be initiated immediately upon diagnosis.
Morning stiffness lasting over an hour is indicative of inflammatory arthritis.
Imaging findings of joint erosions are required for diagnosis.
Disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) are not effective in early stages of the disease.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of morning stiffness, along with pain and swelling in her small joints, particularly in the fingers and wrists. She also notes fatigue and difficulty performing daily tasks, such as opening jars or typing. Physical examination reveals tenderness and swelling in the metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints bilaterally. Laboratory tests show elevated ESR and CRP levels, and she is positive for anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies. Which of the following statement is correct regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Morning stiffness lasting over an hour is indicative of inflammatory arthritis.

 

The clinical presentation, including prolonged morning stiffness, pain, and swelling in the small joints, along with elevated inflammatory markers (ESR and CRP) and positive anti-CCP antibodies, strongly suggests rheumatoid arthritis (RA), a chronic inflammatory autoimmune disease.

 

Morning stiffness: One of the hallmark features of RA is prolonged morning stiffness that typically lasts for more than an hour. This is due to inflammation in the joints and surrounding tissues.

 

Inflammatory arthritis: RA is characterized by chronic inflammation primarily affecting the synovial joints. It commonly affects women, especially those over 60. The disease often starts with symmetrical polyarthritis, involving multiple joints, especially in the morning. The metacarpophalangeal (MCP), proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints, wrists, and other joints are frequently involved.

 

Inflammatory markers and genetic predisposition: Elevated ESR and CRP levels are common in RA, indicating systemic inflammation. Additionally, HLA-DR4 positivity is associated with RA and may influence the severity of the disease.

 

Treatment: While NSAIDs can provide symptomatic relief for pain and inflammation, they do not alter the disease course. Disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs), such as methotrexate, are crucial for controlling RA and preventing long-term joint damage.

 

Diagnosis and Disease Progression: The absence of bone erosions on imaging does not rule out RA, especially in its early stages. Erosions are a later feature and are associated with disease severity and poor functional outcomes. Advanced cases of RA may present with deformities like ulnar deviation, Boutonniere, and Swan neck deformities

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Biologic agents are first-line therapy and should be initiated immediately upon diagnosis: Biologics are not the first-line treatment; DMARDs, particularly methotrexate, are the initial therapy. Biologics are generally used when DMARDs fail to control disease activity.

 

Option C. Imaging findings of joint erosions are required for diagnosis: Joint erosions are not necessary for the initial diagnosis of inflammatory arthritis. Early diagnosis relies on clinical features, serological markers, and inflammatory markers before erosive changes develop.

 

Option D. Disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) are not effective in early stages of the disease: DMARDs are highly effective in early stages and are the cornerstone of treatment in inflammatory arthritis to prevent joint damage and improve outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:


Morning stiffness lasting more than an hour is a hallmark of inflammatory arthritis and helps distinguish it from other joint disorders. Early use of DMARDs is crucial to control inflammation, prevent joint damage, and improve long-term outcomes.

questions.text: A 60-year-old postmenopausal woman comes with a history of Colles’ fracture 6 months ago. Her DEXA scan reveals T score of -2.5. What is the next best step?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Alendronate

 

OSTEOPOROSIS (V > H > C)

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • Bone mineral density is measured by DEXA scan (65 years onwards).
  • Normal Ca2+, PO‑4, ALP
  • Hemiplegic – Humerus maximum loss of bone mineral density.

 

 

  • Etiology:

 

 

  • Radiological Investigation: 
    • Quantitative CT is a newer imaging technique that can be used to detect osteoporosis.
    • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae

 

  • Singh’s Index is used for osteoporosis grading.

 

  • Treatment:
    1. Inhibit resorption: Bisphosphonates (drug of choice), Denosumab, calcitonin, estrogen, SERMS, gallium nitrate.
    2. Stimulate formation: Teriparatide (PTH analogue), calcium, calcitriol, fluorides.
    3. Both actions: Strontium ranelate
       
  • Alendronate:
    • Alendronate is approved for the treatment of postmenopausal osteoporosis, steroid-induced osteoporosis, and male osteoporosis.
    • Alendronate belongs to the class of bisphosphonate medications, which aids in the prevention of bone resorption and the promotion of bone density, making it a valuable treatment for osteoporosis.
    • Alendronate is an option for maintaining or increasing bone mass, whereas risedronate is preferred in men with osteoporosis.
    • It inhibit bone resorption at rates 1000 times greater than the effect on bone formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Calcium and Vitamin D. They are given along with the bisphosphonates but are not the only treatment choice. Calcium is given at a dose of 1500 mg/day. Vitamin D is given at the dose of 400-800 IU per day. Initially, Vit. D deficient patients are treated with active metabolite 1,25, dihydroxy Vit D3 (short half-life 4 hours and expensive) then changing over to longer lasting and less expensive Vit D2 or D3 (t ½ up to 2½ months).

 

Option B. Hormone replacement therapy. The mainstay of bone loss prevention in postmenopausal osteoporosis is estrogen treatment. Daily dose of 0.625 mg of conjugated estrogen in combination with progestins are recommended. Progestin is essential (even though it has no independent effect on bone) to reduce the risk of developing endometrial cancer (due to estrogen).

 

Option D. Repeat DEXA scan after 6 months. The DEXA scan is repeated after 6 months to 1 year after starting of the drug treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alendronate, a drug of class of bisphosphonates is the drug of choice for the treatment of osteoporosis.

choices.text: Horizontal nystagmus towards the same side
Vertical nystagmus towards the same side
Horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side
Vertical nystagmus towards the opposite side

questions.text: During the process of conducting a caloric test, what kind of nystagmus should one anticipate when using cold water irrigation?(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side

 

In caloric testing, cold water irrigation produces horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side.

 

Fitzgerald-Hallpike test or bithermal caloric test procedure:

 

  • Patient is made to lie supine with the head tilted 30° forward so that the horizontal canal is vertical.

 

 

  • Irrigation stimulates the lateral/ horizontal semicircular canal which produces horizontal nystagmus.
  • Cold water induces nystagmus to the opposite side and warm water to the same side (remember mnemonic COWS: cold-opposite, warm-same)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Horizontal nystagmus towards the same side: This option is incorrect for cold water irrigation. Cold water causes the fluid in the horizontal semicircular canal to move in a way that induces nystagmus towards the opposite side, not the same side.

 

Option B. Vertical nystagmus towards the same side and Option D.
