Vertical nystagmus towards the opposite side: Vertical nystagmus does not occur in caloric testing, as this test specifically stimulates the horizontal semicircular canal, inducing horizontal nystagmus. Vertical nystagmus is generally associated with different pathologies and is not a result of standard caloric testing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The caloric test, particularly when using cold water, is designed to stimulate the horizontal semicircular canal, resulting in horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side. This test is critical for evaluating unilateral weaknesses in the vestibular system and helps in diagnosing conditions affecting balance and spatial orientation.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, page No. 45

choices.text: Cavitatory lesions with surrounding ground glass opacities

questions.text: Which of the following findings are seen in a high-resolution CT scan of fungal pneumonia?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cavitatory lesions with surrounding ground glass opacities 

 

Explanation:

 

Invasive aspergillosis

 

  1. HALO SIGN – Multiple nodules with central solid part and haziness around the lesion
  2. Seen in immunocompromised individuals with febrile neutropenia
  3. DOC – voriconazole

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kerley lines: Commonly associated with interstitial edema and pulmonary congestion, not specifically fungal pneumonia.

 

Option B. Hilar lymph nodes: While enlargement can be seen in various conditions, it is not a specific finding for fungal pneumonia.

 

Option C. Pleural effusion: Although it may be present in various lung infections and conditions, it is not characteristic of fungal infections like invasive aspergillosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cavitatory lesions with surrounding ground glass opacities on a high-resolution CT scan are indicative of fungal infections like invasive aspergillosis, especially in immunocompromised patients. Recognition of these signs is crucial for the timely initiation of appropriate antifungal therapy.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents with breathlessness and chest pain. She is a known case of mitral stenosis. Her pulse is irregularly irregular. No thrombus is seen on echocardiography. What can be done to prevent future thrombotic events? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Oral warfarin

 

The patient is diagnosed with mitral stenosis and has an irregularly irregular pulse, indicating atrial fibrillation (AF). Atrial fibrillation is a common complication in patients with mitral stenosis and significantly increases the risk of thromboembolic events.

 

Long-term anticoagulation therapy is essential in such patients to prevent these events. The presence of mitral stenosis, particularly moderate to severe, mandates the use of oral anticoagulants. Warfarin is the recommended anticoagulant in this scenario because it is the only approved medication for patients with mitral stenosis and those with mechanical prosthetic heart valves.

 

Other anticoagulants, such as Direct Oral Anticoagulants (DOACs), are not recommended in patients with valvular atrial fibrillation (AF associated with mitral stenosis or mechanical heart valves).

 

Additional Information –

 

CHA2DS2-VASc score to guide anticoagulation therapy in patients without mitral stenosis or a prosthetic valve.

 

  • C - Congestive heart failure: 1 point
  • H - Hypertension: 1 point
  • A - Age 65 to 74: 1 point, Age 75 and above: 2 points
  • D - Diabetes Mellitus: 1 point
  • S2 - Prior stroke or TIA: 2 points
  • Sex category (Female): 1 point
  • Vascular diseases (such as coronary artery disease or peripheral artery disease): 1 point

 

Scoring and Treatment Recommendations

 

  • Total Points: Ranges from 0 to 9.
  • Score of 2 or more: Strongly indicates the need for long-term anticoagulation (DOAC > warfarin).

 

Direct Oral Anticoagulants (DOACs) such as Dabigatran, Apixaban, Rivaroxaban, or Edoxaban are preferred unless the patient has conditions like mitral stenosis or mechanical prosthetic valves, in which case Warfarin might be more appropriate.

 

  • Score less than 2: Anticoagulation may be considered but is less mandatory.

 

This scoring system is crucial for making informed decisions about anticoagulation therapy to prevent stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation, tailoring treatment based on individual risk profiles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dabigatran: Dabigatran is a DOAC that is not recommended for patients with mitral stenosis or mechanical heart valves. It is suitable for non-valvular atrial fibrillation but not for valvular AF.

 

Option B. Aspirin 150mg: Aspirin is not sufficient as an anticoagulant in patients with atrial fibrillation, especially those with mitral stenosis. It does not provide the necessary anticoagulation to prevent thromboembolic events in such high-risk patients.

 

Option D. Aspirin + Clopidogrel: This combination is also inadequate for anticoagulation in atrial fibrillation, particularly in patients with mitral stenosis. While it can prevent platelet aggregation, it does not provide the anticoagulation required to prevent thrombus formation in atrial fibrillation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with atrial fibrillation associated with mitral stenosis, oral warfarin is the recommended anticoagulant to prevent thromboembolic events.

choices.text: 1-F, 2- E, 3-D, 4- B
1-F, 2-E, 3-B, 4-A

questions.text: Match the following drugs poisoning with the antidotes:(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1-F, 2-E, 3-B, 4-A

 

1. HCN (Hydrogen Cyanide):

 

  • Antidote: F. Amyl nitrite
    HCN poisoning, also known as cyanide poisoning, is treated with amyl nitrite, which induces methemoglobinemia, allowing cyanide to bind to methemoglobin instead of cytochrome oxidase, reducing its toxicity. The DOC for cyanide poisoning is Hydroxocobalamine.

 

2. Paracetamol (Acetaminophen):

 

  • Antidote: E. N-acetylcysteine
    N-acetylcysteine replenishes glutathione stores, helping detoxify the reactive metabolite of paracetamol, thereby preventing liver damage.

 

3. Morphine:

 

  • Antidote: B. Nalorphine
    Nalorphine is an opioid antagonist used to counteract the effects of opioid overdose, including morphine.

 

4. Nicotine:

 

  • Antidote: A. Trimethadione
    Trimethadione is used in cases of nicotine poisoning due to its ganglionic blocking properties, similar to the Nn receptor blockers (ganglionic blockers) like Trimethaphan and Hexamethonium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • HCN poisoning: DOC is Hydroxocobalamin. Amyl Nitrite(inhalational) with sodium thiosulphate (iv) can also be used.
  • Paracetamol poisoning (causes hepatoxicity): N-acetylcysteine is used.
  • Morphine poisoning: DOC is Naloxone. Nalorphine can also be used.
  • Nicotine poisoning: Trimethaphan and Hexamethonium – Nn receptor blockers

(ganglionic blockers) are used.

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/590, 223, 509, 134

questions.text: Treatment of open fracture of femur: (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Open reduction and external fixation 

 

OPEN FRACTURES

 

  • An open fracture occurs when the bone breaks through the skin. 
  • These typically result from high-energy injuries and are often associated with significant damage to the surrounding soft tissues and contamination of the wound. 
  • These injuries are classified into three types according to the Gustillo-Anderson Classification:

 

 

  • All open fractures are emergencies.
  • These injuries require immediate administration of antibiotics and irrigation and debridement of the wound. 
  • The goal of the treatment is to achieve fracture healing and to prevent wound infections and osteomyelitis. 
  • They are frequently associated with injuries to surrounding vessels and nerves, which must be addressed as well. 
  • When the wound is contaminated, an external fixator is initially used. 
  • Early coverage of the wound is important to avoid infection. 
  • Immediately debride the wound of contaminated and devitalized tissue, copiously irrigate, and repeat debridement within 24-72 hours (Delayed wound closure is preferable).
  • Type and method of fixation:

 

 

  • In External fixation, the fixation device is external to skin –Ilizarov fixator.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Closed reduction and internal fixation: Closed reduction is not done for an open fracture. An open fracture inherently involves a break in the skin and contamination. It requires surgical exploration, debridement, and irrigation of the wound in the operating room. Attempting a closed reduction would significantly increase the risk of deep infection (osteomyelitis). Internal fixation (e.g., with an intramedullary nail) can be used for less severe open fractures (Gustilo-Anderson Type I, II, and sometimes IIIA), after thorough open debridement. However, the combination with closed reduction makes this option incorrect for an open fracture.

 

Option D. Closed reduction and external fixation: Closed reduction is incorrect for an open fracture due to the necessity of open wound management. External fixation is a valid and often preferred method of stabilization for open fractures, particularly severe ones or as a temporary measure. However, the initial phase must involve open management of the wound.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The open fractures are best treated with open reduction and external fixation with the use of external fixators like ilizarov fixator.

choices.text: Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis (DISH)

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the clinic with persistent lower back pain and stiffness that has been ongoing for the past year. He reports that the pain is worse in the morning and improves with physical activity throughout the day. He denies any recent trauma or injury. Physical examination reveals reduced range of motion of the lumbar spine. X-rays of the lumbar spine and pelvis show fusion of the sacroiliac joints and syndesmophytes along the spine, creating a "bamboo spine" appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ankylosing spondylitis

 

The patient's clinical presentation of chronic lower back pain and stiffness, particularly worse in the morning and improving with activity, along with the characteristic radiographic findings of sacroiliac joint fusion and syndesmophytes leading to a "bamboo spine" appearance, strongly suggests ankylosing spondylitis (AS).

 

Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic inflammatory disease primarily affecting the spine and sacroiliac joints. It is classified as a seronegative spondyloarthropathy, meaning it is not associated with rheumatoid factor. It typically presents in young adults, with males being more commonly affected, often between the ages of 15-25. The hallmark of AS is inflammatory back pain that is worse in the morning and improves with exercise.

 

Radiographic findings:

 

  • Loss of lumbar lordosis: The normal inward curve of the lower spine is reduced or lost, leading to a straightened posture.
  • Sacroiliitis: Inflammation of the sacroiliac joints, often the earliest manifestation of AS.
  • Syndesmophytes: Bony growths that bridge the intervertebral spaces, leading to the characteristic "bamboo spine" appearance, where the vertebrae appear fused together.
  • Other characteristic signs like the dagger sign (calcification of the supraspinous and interspinous ligaments) and the trolley/tram-track sign (three linear radiopaque lines due to ligament calcification) may also be present.

 

HLA-B27 is a genetic marker strongly associated with AS, being positive in about 90% of patients.

 

AS can also have extra-articular manifestations, such as anterior uveitis (inflammation of the eye).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis (DISH): DISH involves calcification of the anterior longitudinal ligament but does not involve the sacroiliac joints or cause the bamboo spine appearance seen in ankylosing spondylitis. It typically lacks inflammatory symptoms.

 

Option C. Psoriatic arthritis: Psoriatic arthritis can affect the spine and sacroiliac joints, but it is usually associated with skin findings of psoriasis and does not produce the characteristic bamboo spine appearance.

 

Option D. Osteoarthritis: Osteoarthritis commonly affects weight-bearing joints and the cervical and lumbar spine, but it does not cause sacroiliac joint fusion or syndesmophyte formation, distinguishing it from ankylosing spondylitis.

 

Educational Objective:


Ankylosing spondylitis presents with chronic back pain, morning stiffness, and characteristic imaging findings such as sacroiliac joint fusion and syndesmophyte formation, leading to a "bamboo spine." Early recognition and management can help reduce symptoms and prevent long-term complications.

questions.text: Most sensitive test for Carpal tunnel syndrome is:(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Durkan’s test

 

CARPAL TUNNEL SYNDROME

 

  • Carpal tunnel syndrome is the most common type of nerve compression syndrome.
  • It occurs when the median nerve is compressed at the wrist.
  • The median nerve extends from the upper arm to the thumb.
  • At the wrist, it passes through a structure called the carpal tunnel.
  • Excess pressure on the wrist may cause swelling, which can lead to Carpal tunnel syndrome.
  • Tests for Carpal tunnel syndrome:
    • Tinel’s sign: In this test, the physician taps over the median nerve at the wrist to see if it produces a tingling sensation in the fingers.
    • Wrist flexion test (or Phalen test): In this test, the patient rests his or her elbows on a table and allows the wrist to fall forward freely. Individuals with Carpal tunnel syndrome will experience numbness and tingling in the fingers within 60 seconds. The more quickly symptoms appear, the more severe the Carpal tunnel syndrome.

 

 

1. Phalen’s test; 2. Reverse Phalen’s test

 

  • Durkan’s test is performed by manual compression of the Carpal tunnel held for up to 30 seconds and recorded as positive if associated with reproduction of distal paresthesias in the median nerve distribution.

 

 

  • Out of these tests, Tinel sign has the highest specificity and Durkan’s test has the highest sensitivity.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Phalen’s test. This test is 42-85% sensitive and 54-98% specific.

 

Option C. Tinel’s sign. This test has the highest specificity but low sensitivity for carpal tunnel syndrome.

 

Option D. Cozen test. This test is sensitive for lateral epicondylitis. Its sensitivity is about 84%.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Tinel sign has the highest specificity and Durkan’s test has the highest sensitivity for carpal tunnel syndrome.

questions.text:
An orthopedic surgeon plans to treat a Colle’s fracture. What are the steps involved in applying a cast for the same?(INICET MAY 2021)

 

  1. Palmar flexion
  2. Traction
  3. Ulnar deviation
  4. Application of plaster of Paris
questions.solution:
Ans. C) II, I, III, IV

 

COLLE’S FRACTURE

 

  • Colles fracture is fracture of lower end of radius at its corticocancellous junction.
  • It mostly occur in post-menopausal osteoporotic elderly women.
  • Symptoms and Signs:
    • Fracture of the distal radius, commonly referred to as a Colle’s fracture, is typically the result of a FOOSH injury (Fall on outstretched hand) with wrist in extension.
    • Patients present with swelling, ecchymosis, tenderness, and painful range of motion of the distal forearm.
    • On examination, the classic “dinner fork” deformity (dorsal displacement of the distal fragment and volar angulation of the distal intact radius with radial shortening) may be identified.

 

 

 

  • Complications:
    • Early complications may include median nerve neuropathy, extensor pollicis longus tendon rupture, and compartment syndrome.
    • Late complications may include radiocarpal arthrosis, complex regional pain syndrome, cosmetic changes of the wrist, and fracture malunion or nonunion.
    • Finger stiffness is most common complication.
    • Malunion is the 2nd most common complication and it leads to dinner fork deformity.
    • Colles fracture is the commonest cause of Sudeck's dystrophy in upper limb.
       
  • Treatment:
    • Non-displaced extra-articular fractures are relatively stable and are treated non-operatively with a long-arm splint acutely  to allow for swelling, then transitioned to a short-arm cast.
    • The cast is applied on opposite forces to displacement. The position of immobilization is:

 

 

  • Displaced fractures should undergo an attempt at closed reduction followed by immobilization in a long-arm sugar-tong splint acutely.
  • Surgical fixation is indicated for distal radius fractures that fail to meet acceptable alignment criteria.
  • Various methods include closed reduction percutaneous  pinning, external fixation, and open reduction internal fixation (ORIF).
  • Technique of closed manipulation:
    • The muscles of forearm must be relaxed, either by general or regional anaesthesia.
    •  The surgeon grasps the injured hand as if he was ‘shaking hands’.

 

 

 

  • The first step is to disimpact the fragments which have often been driven together.
  • This is achieved by firm longitudinal traction to the hand against the counter-traction by an assistant who grasps the arm above the flexed elbow.
  • The surgeon now presses the distal fragment into palmar flexion and ulnar deviation using the thumb of his other hand.
  • As this is done, the patient’s hand is drawn into pronation, palmar flexion and ulnar deviation.
  • A plaster cast is applied extending from below the elbow to the metacarpal heads, maintaining

 

Educational Objective:

 

Steps of cast application in Colles fracture are:

 

Traction

↓

Palmar flexion

↓

Ulnar deviation

↓

Application of plaster of Paris

questions.text: The image given shows a patient who has undergone total laryngectomy due to laryngeal cancer. Identify the method of voice generation for this patient, as depicted in the provided image.(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tracheoesophageal prosthesis

 

The voice production modality depicted in the image is tracheoesophageal voice prosthesis.

 

The extended air from the trachea is diverted to the esophagus through a device that connects the trachea and esophagus in tracheoesophageal prosthesis. It also has a one-way valve that keeps food from entering into the trachea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Electrolarynx: Is a vibrating instrument that emits a low-pitched sound in the hypopharynx. The palate, tongue, and teeth then articulate it.

 

Option B. Chicago implant: Is a type of hearing aid.

 

Option D. Esophageal speech: The patient is trained to swallow air and slowly release it into the pharynx. 6-10 words can be spoken in a rough manner before re-swallowing the air.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tracheoesophageal prosthesis is a common and effective method for voice restoration following total laryngectomy. It relies on a surgically implanted device that directs air into the esophagus where vibrations are created for speech, significantly enhancing the quality of life for patients who have lost their natural voice box.

questions.text: What is the best imaging study for diagnosis of cerebral infarct?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diffuse weighted MRI

 

Explanation:

 

Diffusion-weighted MRI is the most sensitive investigation for diagnosis of cerebral ischemia.  It is particularly useful for identifying acute ischemic changes in the brain due to its ability to detect diffusion restriction of water molecules in the brain tissue.

 

 

Diffusion restriction: hyperintense on DWI and hypointense on ADC.

 

  • Diffusion restriction is seen with:
    1. Acute stroke
    2. Hypercellular tumors
    3. Abscess
    4. Epidermoid cyst
    5. Keratin-Craniopharyngioma/ Cholesteatoma

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. FLAIR MRI: Fluid-Attenuated Inversion Recovery (FLAIR) MRI is useful for identifying older infarcts and chronic changes but is less sensitive in the acute phase of a stroke.

 

Option B. Non-contrast CT: While commonly used for initial assessment due to its availability and speed, it is less sensitive in the early stages of a stroke, often not showing changes until several hours post-onset.

 

Option D. СECT (Contrast-Enhanced CT): Typically used to assess for complications or other causes of symptoms but not as sensitive as DWI for early detection of cerebral infarcts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diffusion-weighted MRI is the optimal choice for early detection of cerebral infarcts, making it an indispensable tool in acute stroke management. Its ability to show diffusion restriction provides critical information that can influence therapeutic decisions.

questions.text: Identify the component responsible for endotoxic shock in gram-negative bacteria? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1

 

1 represents the lipopolysaccharide component which is responsible for endotoxic shock in a gram-negative cell wall.

 

 

Conventional gram-negative (LPS-diderm) bacteria display these characteristics:

 

  • An inner cell membrane is present (cytoplasmic)
  • A thin peptidoglycan layer is present (this is much thicker in gram-positive bacteria)
  • Has outer membrane containing lipopolysaccharides (LPS, which consists of lipid A, core polysaccharide, and O antigen) in its outer leaflet and phospholipids in the inner leaflet
  • Porins exist in the outer membrane, which act like pores for particular molecules
  • Between the outer membrane and the cytoplasmic membrane there is a space filled with a concentrated gel-like substance called periplasm
  • The S-layer is directly attached to the outer membrane rather than to the peptidoglycan
  • If present, flagella have four supporting rings instead of two
  • Teichoic acids or lipoteichoic acids are absent
  • Lipoproteins are attached to the polysaccharide backbone
  • Some contain Braun's lipoprotein, which serves as a link between the outer membrane and the peptidoglycan chain by a covalent bond

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2: Incorrect: Number 2 represents the flagella, which are responsible for bacterial motility, not endotoxic shock.

 

Option B. 4: Incorrect: Number 4 represents the cytoplasmic membrane, which is not involved in causing endotoxic shock.

 

Option D. 3: Incorrect: Number 3 represents the peptidoglycan layer, which provides structural support to the bacterial cell wall but does not contribute to endotoxic shock.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Differences between exotoxins and endotoxins

questions.text: As a young pediatrician practicing in India, you attend various workshops and training sessions to keep yourself updated with the latest guidelines in child health. During one such session focused on India's National Immunization Program, you discuss with your colleagues about the range of vaccines included in the program. Which of the following vaccines is NOT currently part of India's National Immunization Program? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Influenza

 

  • The Influenza vaccine (commonly known as the Flu shot) has not yet been included in India's National Immunization Programme.
  • It's important to note that the Bacterial Hemophilus influenzae type-b (Hib) vaccine is distinct from the viral Influenza (Flu) vaccine.
  • The HiB vaccine is included as part of the pentavalent vaccine (DPT + HiB + HepB).

 

Educational Objective:

 

NEW National Immunization Schedule (NIS) 2023-24

questions.text: 3-point bony relationship is maintained in which fracture?(INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Supracondylar humerus fracture

 

THREE POINT BONY LANDMARKS IN ELBOW

 

  • Tips of medial and lateral epicondyles and olecranon
  • Form isosceles triangle with elbow in 90° flexion
  • Lie transversely in straight line in elbow extension

 

 

  • Three-point bony relationship is not disturbed in fracture supracondylar humerus as the fracture occurs above the level of these bony landmarks.
  • With disturbed (increased) intercondylar distance: 
    • Fracture lateral epicondyle and condyle
    • Fracture medial epicondyle and condyle
    • Fracture intercondylar humerus.
  • With maintained intercondylar distance: 
    • Fracture olecranon (i.e. upper end ulna)
    • Elbow dislocation (classical example)
  • Waeak posterior capsule may disrupt three-point bony relation by promoting subluxation or dislocations of elbow.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elbow dislocation. In elbow dislocation, the intercondylar distance is maintained but the three-point bony relationship is disturbed.

 

Option C. Intercondylar humerus fracture. In this fracture, the intercondylar distance is disturbed i.e., increased, so is the three-point bony relationship.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The three-point bony relationship of the elbow is maintained only in the supracondylar humerus fracture because this fracture occurs above the bony landmarks associated with the relation.

questions.text: A 60-year-old postmenopausal woman visits her physician for an evaluation of her bone health due to concerns about osteoporosis. She has no history of fractures but reports a decrease in height over the past few years. The physician explains that assessing bone mineral density is crucial to diagnose osteoporosis and prevent fractures. Several imaging techniques are discussed during the visit. Which of the following radiological investigations is NOT used for diagnosing osteoporosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bone scintigraphy

 

Bone Scintigraphy

 

Bone scintigraphy, also known as a bone scan, is an imaging technique that detects areas of increased or abnormal bone metabolism using radioactive tracers. It is primarily used to detect conditions with increased bone turnover, such as fractures, bone infections, bone tumours, and metastasis, but not for diagnosing osteoporosis.

 

Osteoporosis is a condition characterized by reduced bone mass and increased susceptibility to fractures. It is primarily diagnosed by measuring bone mineral density (BMD) using a DEXA scan (Dual-Energy X-ray Absorptiometry). The World Health Organization (WHO) classifies osteoporosis based on T-scores, with a T-score of less than -2.5 indicating osteoporosis.

 

Radiological features of osteoporosis: On X-rays, osteoporosis can manifest as a loss of vertical height of vertebrae, vertebral collapse, and a characteristic "codfish" appearance where the superior and inferior surfaces of the vertebrae become concave.

 

Treatment:

  • Estrogen: Used in some cases, though with caution due to associated risks.
  • Bisphosphonates: First-line treatment for osteoporosis, though they have been associated with an increased risk of atypical fractures, particularly of the hip.
  • Calcitonin: Used as a second-line treatment.
  • Low-dose PTH (Parathyroid Hormone): Stimulates osteoblasts and is used in certain cases to promote bone formation

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dual-energy X-ray Absorptiometry (DEXA): DEXA is the gold standard for diagnosing osteoporosis, measuring BMD at the hip and spine and providing a T-score that compares the patient's BMD to that of a healthy young adult.

 

Option C. Quantitative CT scan: QCT is another imaging technique that can be used to measure bone mineral density, particularly at the spine. It offers a volumetric assessment of BMD and can also assess bone microarchitecture, making it valuable in detecting early vertebral changes

 

Option D. Peripheral DXA (pDXA): Peripheral DXA measures bone density at peripheral sites, such as the forearm or heel, and is used as a screening tool for osteoporosis, especially when central DEXA is not readily available.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Bone scintigraphy is not used for diagnosing osteoporosis as it measures bone metabolism rather than bone density. DEXA remains the primary method for assessing bone mineral density and diagnosing osteoporosis, with other modalities like quantitative CT and peripheral DXA serving as supplemental tools.

questions.text:
Which of the following investigations are not used for diagnosing osteoporosis?(INICET NOV 2020)

 

  1. DEXA
  2. Bone scan
  3. Quantitative CT
  4. Chemical analysis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) II, IV are correct

 

OSTEOPOROSIS (V > H > C)

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • Bone mineral density is measured by DEXA scan (65 years onwards)
  • Normal Ca2+, PO‑4, ALP
  • Hemiplegic – Humerus maximum loss of bone mineral density

 

 

  • Radiological Investigation: 
    • Quantitative CT is a newer imaging technique that can be used to detect osteoporosis
    • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae.

 

 

  • Treatment:
    • Estrogen
    • Bisphosphonates – Increases hip fracture.
    • Calcitonin
    • Low dose PTH – Stimulates osteoblasts.

 

Other Options:

 

  • A bone scan helps to examine any irregularities in the bone. Sometimes, these bone irregularities may indicate either infection or cancer disease. In addition, it can also help to detect arthritis and bone fractures.

  • Chemical analysis test will not show any diagnostic change because the serum calcium, phosphate, and alkaline phosphatase levels remains normal in osteoporosis. The problem with osteoporosis is of bone quality and not its chemical makeup.

     

Educational Objective:

 

  • DEXA scan is the investigation of choice.
  • Quantitative CT is a bone mineral density (BMD) measurement technique in which the CT scanner is calibrated using solid phantoms (made of calcium hydroxyapatite, representing various bone mineral densities) placed under the patient in a pad. With this calibration, the Hounsfield units are converted to bone mineral density values. The technique can be used for both peripheral and central BMD measurements, with lumbar spine and hip being preferred locations.
  • DEXA measures the bone mineral density of both the outer (cortical) shell and the inner (trabecular) structure of the bone. QCT, on the other hand, measures only the inner part. Because of this difference, QCT studies of the spine show a lower T-score than a DEXA would.

choices.text: a, b, c, d are correct

questions.text:
Evaluate the following statements with respect to CTEV.(AIIMS NOV 2019)

 

  1. 50% cases are in males and are bilateral
  2. Forefoot is adducted and supinated
  3. With Ponsetti technique, correction is up to 90%
  4. Equinus should be corrected first
questions.solution:
Ans. A. a, b, c are correct

 

  • CTEV is a congenital foot deformity characterized by several components:

    • Cavus: High arch

    • Adduction: Forefoot turned inward

    • Supination: Sole of the foot turned inward

    • Equinus: Plantarflexion 

    • Varus: Inversion of the heel

 

a. 50% cases are in males and are bilateral: 

 

  • Clubfoot is more common in males than females. The ratio is roughly 2:1. So, more than 50% of cases are in males.

  • Approximately 50% of all clubfoot cases occur in both feet (bilateral).

 

b. Forefoot is adducted and supinated:

 

  • This statement is correct. 

  • As mentioned earlier, forefoot adduction and supination are key components of the clubfoot deformity.

 

c. With Ponsetti technique, correction is up to 90%:

 

  • This statement is considered correct. 

  • The Ponseti method, a non-surgical treatment involving serial casting, has very high success rates, often reported around 90% or even higher when followed properly.

 

Other Option:

 

d. Equinus should be corrected first:

 

  • This statement is incorrect. 

  • The Ponseti method typically follows a specific sequence of correction:

    1. Cavus: Addressing the high arch first.

    2. Adduction and Supination: Correcting the inward turning of the forefoot.

    3. Varus: Correcting the inversion of the heel.

    4. Equinus: Addressing the plantarflexion of the foot, often as the final step.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In CTEV, male children are more affected than females. 

  • 50% of cases of CTEV have bilateral lower limb involvement. 

  • There is forefoot adduction and supination in cases of CTEV. 

  • Ponseti method of conservative treatment gives correction of up to 90%. 

 

Equinus deformity is corrected at last, following the C-A-V-E sequence.

questions.text: A child presents with cyanosis. His chest radiograph is shown below. What is the diagnosis?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario and chest X-ray showing a boot-shaped heart are suggestive of tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).

 

TOF is a cyanotic congenital heart disease comprised of four components:

 

  1. Right ventricular hypertrophy –Boot shaped heart
  2. Ventricular septal defect – no heart failure
  3. Overriding of aorta
  4. Pulmonary stenosis (infundibulum)-Oligemia

 

If ASD plus – pentalogy of Fallot

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ebstein's anomaly: Typically presents with an enlarged and downward displacement of the tricuspid valve into the right ventricle, which is not specifically indicated by the features in this X-ray.

 

Option B. Transposition of great arteries (TGA): Generally shows a characteristic "egg on a string" sign on chest X-ray, which is not evident in this image.

 

Option D. Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVC): Would show features like a "snowman" or "figure of 8" heart due to dilatation of the supra-cardiac veins, which is not visible here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tetralogy of Fallot is characterized by a distinctive boot-shaped heart on chest X-ray, correlating with the anatomical components of this congenital heart defect, making it a key diagnostic feature in cyanotic pediatric patients.

questions.text: In the fracture seen in the X-ray below, what is the most commonly expected vascular injury?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Brachial artery

 

  • The given image shows the supracondylar fracture of the humerus.
  • Fracture supracondylar humerus is:
    • Most common fracture associated with vascular injury.
    • Most common fracture to involve brachial artery (10% cases).
    • Most common cause of volkmann's ischemia and compartment syndrome in children.
    • Most common cause of volkmann's ischemic contracture.
    • Non-union is unknown.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Radial artery. It can be associated with the fracture of the distal radius.

 

Option C. Ulnar artery. It can be associated with the comminuted fracture of the distal radius.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows the supracondylar humerus fracture which is mostly associated with the brachial artery injury.

choices.text: ERG shows decreased amplitude of a and b wave
Late presentation is loss of peripheral vision
Night blindness is a late feature

questions.text: Which of the following statement is incorrect about Retinitis Pigmentosa? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Night blindness is a late feature

 

Retinitis Pigmentosa (RP) is a group of hereditary disorders that cause progressive degeneration of the retina, specifically affecting the photoreceptors (rods and cones).

 

Night blindness is a late feature: This is incorrect. Night blindness (nyctalopia) is an early feature of RP. Patients often present with difficulties in dark adaptation and night vision long before significant peripheral vision loss occurs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ERG shows decreased amplitude of a and b wave: Electroretinography (ERG) in RP patients shows decreased amplitude of both the a wave (originating from rods and cones) and the b wave (originating from bipolar cells).

 

Option B. Rod dystrophy > Cone dystrophy: RP typically starts with rod dysfunction, which later involves the cones.

 

Option C. Late presentation is loss of peripheral vision: RP usually presents with mid-peripheral vision loss, which progresses to peripheral vision loss and eventually central vision loss, leading to tunnel vision.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Night blindness is an early feature of Retinitis Pigmentosa, not a late one. The initial symptoms typically include difficulties with night vision.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presented to the emergency department with the sudden onset of severe epigastric pain, she had a history of heart burn and dyspeptic symptoms for past 10 years. On physical exam, she had a temperature of 101.44° F, a pulse of 115bpm and a blood pressure of 125/72mmHg. Abdomen was tender & rigid. What is the likely diagnosis?(AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pneumoperitoneum  

 

Explanation:

 

The presence of free gas under the right diaphragm in the X-ray. This is suggestive of pneumoperitoneum.

 

  • C/F: Acute abdominal pain, rigidity, tenderness, guarding
  • MOST SENSITIVE X RAY: CXR-PA erect

 

 

 

Air under the diaphragm-Right

 

  • MOST SENSITIVE Ix: CECT with oral contrast
  • NEXT STEP: Resuscitation with iv fluids, Exploratory laparotomy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumothorax which represents air in the pleural space, collapsed lung and sometimes mediastinal shift to the opposite side. Presentation is variable and may range from no symptoms to severe dyspnea with tachycardia and hypotension. 

 

Option C. Subdiaphragmatic abscess, there is an infradiaphragmatic localized collection of fluid with gas bubbles or gas-fluid level which has an enhancing wall. It is often combined with elevation of the hemidiaphragm and a pleural effusion.

 

Option D. Intestinal obstruction on abdominal radiographs show dilated loops of small bowel proximal to the obstruction with visible valvulae conniventes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumoperitoneum is a critical diagnosis identified by the presence of free air under the diaphragm on X-ray, indicative of gastrointestinal perforation, requiring immediate surgical intervention.

choices.text: ACL and medial collateral ligament injury
Lateral collateral ligament injury
Medial meniscus injury

questions.text: The injury shown in the radiograph can result in: (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. ACL injury

 

SEGOND FRACTURE

 

  • Segond fracture is an avulsion fracture of the knee that involves the lateral aspect of the tibial plateau and is very frequently (»75% of cases) associated with disruption of the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL).
  • On the frontal knee radiograph, it may appear as a curvilinear or elliptic bone fragment projected parallel to the lateral aspect of the tibial plateau, referred to as the lateral capsular sign.

 

 

  • Contrary to the more common causes of an ACL tear, which typically involves valgus stress, a Segond fracture usually occurs as a result of internal rotation and varus stress.
  • Treatment:
  • Although the fracture itself is small, the extensive ligamentous injury associated with it usually requires surgical intervention.
  • Spontaneous healing of the Segond fracture may occur following ACL reconstruction.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given image in the question shows Segond fracture, which is frequently seen with ACL injuries.

questions.text: A young patient with RTA sustained an open fracture of femur which was operated and stabilized as shown below. Identify the fixator.(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rail fixator

 

OPEN FRACTURES

 

  • An open fracture occurs when the bone breaks through the skin.
  • These typically result from high-energy injuries and are often associated with significant damage to the surrounding soft tissues and contamination of the wound.
  • Phalanges followed by tibia is the most common site.
  • These injuries are classified into three types according to the Gustillo-Anderson

 

 

  • These injuries require immediate administration of antibiotics and irrigation and debridement of the wound.
  • The goal of the treatment is to achieve fracture healing and to prevent wound infections and osteomyelitis.
  • When the wound is contaminated, an external fixator is initially used.
  • Early coverage of the wound is important to avoid infection.
  • In general, an increase in Gustillo grade is associated with an increase in infection risk.
  • External Fixation:
    • In external fixation the fixation device is external to skin-external fixator or Ilizarov fixator.
    • Ilizarov fixator works on the principles of distraction osteogenesis that is an osteotomy is carried out and distracted at the rate of 1 mm per day causing distraction at the callus and subsequently lengthening can be done. It can be used for correction of deformities like malunion, shortening, shortening with discharging sinus, gap non-union and also for CTEV.
    • Open fracture is one of the most common cause for segmental loss of bone.
    • For treating bone gap when Ilizarov ring fixator is used, it achieves union, eradicates infection, corrects deformities, reestablishes limb length and at the same time maintains function.
    • The Rail Fixator is designed for bone transport for reconstructing bone loss following open fracture and sequestrectomy following osteomyelitis. It provides correction through bone transport, compression-distraction and bifocal lengthening. 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. K-nail. Femoral shaft fractures are one of the commonest high energy fractures, and intramedullary nailing is the gold standard management of these fractures. Intramedullary fixation is considered superior to plate fixation because of lower rates of infection, early weight-bearing, and lesser chances of non-union. Unlocked Kuntscher nail (K-nail) should only be used for isthmic femoral shaft fractures. The main drawback of K-nail for use in other types of femoral shaft fracture was lack of rotational stability. Nowadays, interlocking intramedullary nail is used for almost all types of femoral shaft fractures because of better rotational stability.

 

 

Option C. Ilizarov fixator. Ilizarov fixator is an effective treatment modality of open comminuted femur fractures with high union rate, adequate alignment and satisfactory functional outcomes. Ilizarov fixator works on the principles of distraction osteogenesis that is an osteotomy is carried out and distracted at the rate of 1 mm per day causing distraction at the callus and subsequently lengthening can be done. It can be used for correction of deformities like malunion, shortening, shortening with discharging sinus, gap non-union and also for CTEV. For treating bone gap when Ilizarov ring fixator is used, it achieves union, eradicates infection, corrects deformities, reestablishes limb length and at the same time maintains function.

 

 

Option D. Proximal femoral nail. The proximal femoral nail (PFN) is an osteosynthetic implant is used to treat proximal femoral fractures in the trochanter area with a closed intramedullary fixation method. It consists of a funnel-shaped intramedullary nail with slight bending to reflect proximal femoral diaphyseal trochanteric morphology. It has two proximal openings, a larger one distally for a large femoral neck lag screw and a smaller one immediately above for a smaller anti-rotation screw/pin. There are small holes at the distal end of the nail for locking screws.  It can be combined with a wire cerclage with an open reduction for additional stability in complicated subtrochanteric fractures.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fixator shown in the image in the question is a Rail Fixator, used to treat open fractures to fill the bone gap.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to the sports medicine clinic with complaints of knee pain and discomfort in his back over the last six months, especially during and after basketball practice. He mentions feeling "off balance" lately and has noticed that one of his shoulders appears higher than the other. On physical examination, there is an asymmetry of his shoulder heights and a noticeable rib hump on the right side when he bends forward. His spine X-ray shows a left lumbar scoliosis with a Cobb angle of 35 degrees. The physician recommends using a brace to prevent the progression of his spinal curvature. Which of the following braces is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Milwaukee brace

 

The patient's presentation with a left lumbar scoliosis with a Cobb angle of 35 degrees suggests a moderate curve. In adolescents with moderate scoliosis, bracing is often recommended to prevent further curve progression during the adolescent growth spurt. Among the given options, the Milwaukee brace is the most appropriate for this patient. Milwaukee brace

 

 

This is a full-torso brace that extends from the pelvis to the neck. It is designed to correct scoliosis curves in the thoracic and lumbar regions of the spine, making it suitable for the patient's left lumbar scoliosis. It is an active corrective spinal orthosis, meaning it actively applies forces to correct the spinal curvature. The Milwaukee brace is particularly effective for treating idiopathic scoliosis, the most common type, where the apex of the curve is at or above T7, with a Cobb angle between 20° and 40°.

 

Scoliosis: Scoliosis is characterized by a lateral curvature of the spine associated with the rotation of the involved vertebrae. It can be classified into four main categories:

 

  • Idiopathic Scoliosis: This is the most common type, typically developing in girls between the ages of 10-12 years. The etiology is multifactorial, with a genetic component involved.
  • Congenital Scoliosis: This form results from vertebral abnormalities due to a failure of formation or segmentation of the affected vertebrae.
  • Neuromuscular Scoliosis: This type is associated with neurological or muscular diseases, such as cerebral palsy or muscular dystrophy.  
  • Syndromic Scoliosis: This type is associated with a known syndrome, such as Marfan syndrome or neurofibromatosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Charleston bending brace: This brace is typically worn only at night and is designed to overcorrect single, flexible curves. It is not suitable for high thoracic curves or for double curves where overcorrection may not be feasible.

 

Option B. SpineCor brace: A dynamic and flexible brace intended for daytime wear, the SpineCor brace allows for some movement but is generally less effective for controlling high thoracic or severe curves compared to rigid braces like the Milwaukee brace.

 

Option D. Wilmington brace: A custom-molded, rigid brace worn full-time, designed primarily for thoracic and lumbar scoliosis with curves below T8. It is less suitable for high thoracic or cervical curves where the Milwaukee brace would be preferred.

 

Educational Objective:


The Milwaukee brace is specifically used for high thoracic and cervical scoliosis curves where other braces may not provide adequate support. It is one of the few braces effective for apex curves above T8, offering rigid support to control curve progression during growth

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with severe back pain, vomiting, and hypotension. CT findings are given below. What is the diagnosis?(AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Renal angiomyolipoma

 

Explanation:

 

The CT image shows a left renal lesion with negative /low attenuation (black in color) that indicate fatty tissue. This is consistent with renal angiomyolipoma. Clinical findings of severe back pain, vomiting, and hypotension and hematoma around the renal mass are suggestive of rupture. This is known as Wunderlich syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Renal cysts are homogeneous hypodense lesions.

 

Option B. Renal cell carcinoma will appear heterogeneous and hypervacular with areas of necrosis.

 

Option C. Para pelvic cyst are  simple renal cysts that plunge into the renal sinus from the adjacent renal parenchyma. A parapelvic cyst at times may cause compression of the pelvicalyceal system resulting in hydronephrosis. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Renal angiomyolipoma is typically composed of fat, muscle, and blood vessels and appears as a low-attenuation mass on CT scans. When associated with symptoms like severe pain and hypotension, it raises concerns for potential hemorrhage or rupture, emphasizing the need for prompt evaluation and management.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the X-ray? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Patella fracture

 

The X-ray provided shows a clear fracture line through the patella, indicating a patella fracture.

 

In the provided image, the presence of a sharp, discontinuous line through the patella confirms the diagnosis of a patella fracture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemarthrosis: This condition would cause swelling in the joint but would not show a fracture line. The X-ray does not indicate swelling without a fracture, ruling out hemarthrosis.

 

 

Option C. Bipartite patella: This is a congenital condition where the patella is naturally in two parts. It shows smooth, well-defined borders unlike the jagged edges seen in fractures. The X-ray here clearly shows a fracture line, not a bipartite patella.

 

 

Option D. Ligament injury: Ligament injuries do not show up on X-rays as they involve soft tissues. Thus, this option is not relevant to the findings on the X-ray.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A patella fracture can be identified on an X-ray by a distinct fracture line through the patella, differentiating it from other conditions like hemarthrosis, bipartite patella, and ligament injuries.

questions.text: Which of the following, all are findings of the condition in the below chest X-ray except: (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pulmonary venous hypertension

 

The chest X-ray provided shows the characteristic "egg-on-a-string" appearance, which is indicative of Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA). In TGA, the aorta arises from the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery arises from the left ventricle, leading to parallel circulation. This is a severe congenital heart defect that requires immediate attention.

 

In TGA, the following findings are seen:

 

  • Right atrial enlargement: This occurs due to increased venous return to the right side of the heart, as blood from the body is directed to the right atrium and ventricle, which then pumps it to the aorta and systemic circulation. This enlargement is visible on the X-ray.
  • Narrow vascular pedicle: The "string" appearance of the mediastinum is due to a narrow vascular pedicle, which is a common radiographic finding in TGA. This narrowness results from the abnormal positioning and arrangement of the great arteries.
  • Increased pulmonary blood flow: Depending on the presence and size of any associated shunts (like a patent ductus arteriosus or a ventricular septal defect), there can be increased pulmonary blood flow, which is often observed in cases of TGA.

 

However, pulmonary venous hypertension is not a typical finding in TGA. Pulmonary venous hypertension is usually seen in conditions that increase pressure in the pulmonary veins, such as left heart failure or mitral valve disease. It is not characteristic of TGA, where the primary issue is with the arteries and not the pulmonary veins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased pulmonary blood flow: This can occur in TGA, especially if there is a shunt allowing some oxygenated blood to reach the systemic circulation.

 

Option B. Narrow vascular pedicle: The "string" part of the "egg-on-a-string" appearance refers to the narrow mediastinum, which is due to the narrow vascular pedicle, a common finding in TGA.

 

Option C. Right atrial enlargement: Right atrial enlargement: Enlargement of the right atrium is seen in TGA due to the abnormal circulation pattern but is a rare feature.
Both atria can enlarge in TGA, but left predominates
With mixing lesions (VSD, ASD), right atrial enlargement can happen

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "egg-on-a-string" appearance on a chest X-ray is characteristic of Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA), and pulmonary venous hypertension is not a typical finding in this condition.
